Summary:
The patient is an 83-year-old male with a history of hypercarbic respiratory failure, pancreatitis, and renal failure. He is currently intubated and on mechanical ventilation due to respiratory failure. He also has anion gap metabolic acidosis, likely secondary to uremia.

The patient's vital signs include a temperature of 102.0°F (38.9°C), heart rate of 72 bpm, blood pressure of 120/67 mmHg, respiratory rate of 27 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 98% on supplemental oxygen. His physical examination shows no peripheral edema, jugular venous distention, or pulmonary crackles. His neurologic examination is not assessed.

The patient's laboratory results show leukocytosis with a white blood cell count of 25.9 K/uL, elevated blood glucose of 311 mg/dL, hypocalcemia with a calcium level of 7.4 mg/dL, hyponatremia with a sodium level of 117 mEq/L, hyperkalemia with a potassium level of 6.5 mEq/L, and elevated creatinine and BUN levels indicating renal dysfunction.

Imaging studies reveal severe pancreatitis with no fluid collections, bilateral pleural effusions with associated lung collapse, and no evidence of valvular regurgitation or valvular pathology on transesophageal echocardiogram (TEE). CT abdomen/pelvis shows no abscess

The patient is an 83-year-old male with a history of hypercarbic respiratory failure, pancreatitis, and renal failure. He is currently intubated and on mechanical ventilation due to COPD exacerbation. He is febrile with leukocytosis and bilateral infiltrates on chest X-ray, suggesting ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP). The patient also has severe pancreatitis with no fluid collections, no abscesses or fluid collections identified on CT abdomen/pelvis, and severe COPD with hypercarbic respiratory failure. He has a history of gallstone pancreatitis and has undergone two ERCP procedures. He has been diagnosed with sepsis, likely secondary to VAP, and is being treated with broad-spectrum antibiotics. Other complications include acute on chronic renal failure, diabetes mellitus, anemia, hypertension, and fluid overload. The patient's condition is described as poor prognosis, and a family meeting has been held to discuss this.

   This pt
s respiratory failure is multifactorial--[**2-26**] inability to
   compensate adequately for metabolic acidosis in setting of  sepsis, and
   renal failure as well as COPD, distended abd, and VAP.  He continues to
   require full ventilator support and is not currently a candidate for
   wean/SBT.  Despite that his gallstone pancreatitis is improving without
   evidence of necrosis/pseudocyst and decreasing a/l and LFTs, he
   continues to have high fevers and profound leukocytosis.  Despite
   ongoing extensive infection evaluation, we have been unable to identify
   a clear etiology/source. Pt remains in MODS with poor prognosis.
   Agree with plan to continue ACV. We will continue current settings.  We
   are temporaizing but limnited in terms of further compensatoing with
   vent for his ongoing/worsening AGMA.  We will monitor his lactate and
   abgs closely. We will cont to discuss with family regarding trach
   placement given prolonged ventilation.
   ---His wbc is down slightly but he remains febrile.  Thgough this may
   be from his pancreatitis that appears to be improving and we are more
   concerned for evolving infections. We continue broad empiric antibx
   coverage for VAP.  We have discussed a broad potential infection ddx
   (including c. diff, UTI,  line infection, fungal infection given tpn,
   recurrent biliary obstruction, acalculous chole, pseudocyst or
   pancreatic necrosis, loculated effusion, sinusitis, SBE) and continue
   extensive infection work-up.Lines were changed yesterday.  Without
   evidence of SBE on TTE though limited study our clincial suspicion of
   this is low. We continue empiric antifungal coverage and c diff
   coverage.  We will change out lines (no growth to date from blood and
   sites without erythema) and obtain SBE to eval for vegetations (low
   clinical suspicion with neg bl cxs and no stigmata of sbe).  We will
   start empiric anti-fungal coverage given risk of [**Female First Name (un) **] from tpn, and
   will continue empiric flagyl for ? c diff  (cx neg X 2, ileus with poor
   GI absorption for PO vanco).  Follow vano levels.  Will consult ID for
   any further input regarding antibx and infectious sources.
   --His acute on CRI is slowly worsening with increasing uremia and gap.
   As we are limtied as to furthe compensation with vent, he will likely
   require HD.  Will consult renal for input.  Continue renal dosing of
   meds.
   --His abd remains distended, likely related to ileus. His OG outpt is
   decreasing slowly.  KUB without obstruction.  He remains NPO given
   bilous output.  We continue to follow bladder pressures, though urine
   outpt remains adequate and there has been no evidence of  abd

Summary:
The patient is an 83-year-old male with a complex medical history including respiratory failure, acute on chronic renal failure, gallstone pancreatitis, profound metabolic acidosis, and hypocalcemia. The patient has been diagnosed with sepsis, acute respiratory failure, abdominal distention, fevers, leukocytosis, acute on chronic renal failure, and severe gallstone pancreatitis.

The patient's respiratory failure is multifactorial, including the inability to compensate adequately for metabolic acidosis in the setting of sepsis, renal failure, COPD, distended abdomen, and ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP). The patient continues to require full ventilator support and is not currently a candidate for weaning or spontaneous breathing trial (SBT).

The patient's gallstone pancreatitis is improving without evidence of necrosis or pseudocyst formation, but he continues to have high fevers and profound leukocytosis. Despite ongoing extensive infection evaluation, the source of infection has not been identified.

The patient is in multiorgan dysfunction syndrome (MODS) with a poor prognosis. The plan is to continue antibiotic coverage for VAP, and the patient will be monitored closely for any signs of infection.

The patient's white blood cell count is down slightly, but he remains febrile. Although this may be due to his improving pancreatitis, there is concern for evolving infections, and broad empiric antibiotic coverage will be continued.

The patient's acute on chronic renal failure is worsening,

Summary:
The patient is an 83-year-old male with sepsis, acute respiratory failure, acute kidney injury, and severe gallstone pancreatitis. He has profound metabolic acidosis, hypocalcemia, and is experiencing ongoing fevers and leukocytosis. The patient requires full ventilator support and is not a candidate for weaning. He also has abdominal distention, ileus, and worsening renal function.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP): The patient has been on mechanical ventilation for an extended period, increasing the risk of developing VAP.
2. Multi-organ dysfunction syndrome (MODS): Given the patient's critical condition and multiple organ dysfunction, there is a high risk of MODS.
3. Acute kidney injury (AKI) progression: The patient's renal function is worsening, and if left untreated, it may progress to end-stage renal disease.
4. Infection: Despite broad-spectrum antibiotic coverage, the patient remains febrile and leukocytosis, indicating a potential ongoing infection.
5. Complications related to pancreatitis: The patient has severe gallstone pancreatitis, which can lead to complications such as pancreatic necrosis, pseudocyst formation, and infected pancreatic necrosis.
6. Abdominal compartment syndrome: The patient's abdominal distention and ileus increase the risk of developing abdominal compartment syndrome.
7. Deep vein thrombosis (DVT): Immobility and critical illness

   Mr. [**Known lastname 9611**] is an 83M with hypercarbic respiratory failure, pancreatitis
   and renal failure.
   # Repiratory failure
 Pt has continued ventilator requirement. He has
   COPD which could have contributed to this respiratory distress. Pt has
   anion gap metabolic acidosis, likely secondary to uremia, he retains
   CO2 at baseline and is unable to breathe off his CO2 to compensate for
   his metabolic acidosis. Now febrile, with leukocytosis with bilateral
   infiltrates on CXR, concerning for VAP (see below). [**Month (only) 51**] also have
   atelectasis from increased abdominal pressure. Barriers to extubation
   include weakness and need to transition him from this metabolic
   acidosis to his baseline.
   - continue on AC vent settings as pt has elevated abdominal pressures
   (again) and metabolic acidosis that requires RR to compensate
   appropriately in setting of chronic resp acidosis from COPD.
   - cannot increase RR too much as pt is [**Name (NI) 9752**], and pt may stack
   breaths. Also, if inceasing RR too much, may end up just ventilating
   dead space.
   -Treatment of VAP (see below)
   - Continue sedation to make pt more comfortable
   - The treatment for uremic acidosis would be dialysis, consult renal
   today
   .
   # COPD
 pt retains CO2 at baseline and is unable to breathe off his
   CO2 to compensate for his metabolic acidosis.
   - Correct metabolic acidosis as above
   - MDIs while on the vent
   .
   # Sepsis
 Pt meets SIRS criteria again for Temp, WBC, and RR. Unclear
   sources. Could be VAP. Cholangitis or continued obstruction is possible
   but not seen on ERCP.  Pancreatic necrosis is less likely given pt
   would appear much more ill and it was not noted on CT [**Last Name (un) **]. Pt may also
   have UTI in setting of foley, bacteremia or infected lines. Urine
   culture neg x2. Blood cx NGTD from [**Date range (1) 9733**]. Lines were changed. C.
   diff negative x2 and LENI negative for DVT. CT sinus ruled out
   sinusitis.  Endocarditis was not seen on TTE.  Osteo remains on the
   differential.
   - Empiric treatment with vanco, zosyn and cipro. Vanc trough low at
   5.7, dose increased from Q48 to Q24.
   - continue empiric antifungal treatment with micafungin
   - will resend another C diff (although neg x 2) and empirically start
   tx with IV flagyl
   - F/u BCx
   - Maintain UOP>30 cc/hr, MAP> 60, monitor CVPs
   - ID consult today
   .
   * Gallstone Pancreatitis - s/p ERCP x2 which showed gallstone
   obstructive pancreatitis.  Pt had partial sphincterotomy with retained
   stone.  Had another ERCP [**2153-9-20**] with old stent removal/new stent
   placement with grossly distended abdomen after.  Abdominal exam showed
   continued distention after initial improvement after OGT placement.
   Pancreatitis improving. Calcium level improving.
   -Trend LFTs, amylase and lipase
   - continue zosyn, vanc and cipro as above
   - OGT in place for GI decompression
   - continue TPN (instead of TF) given increased abdominal distention,
   will transition to TF when pt has less OGT output
   - check bladder pressures [**Hospital1 7**]
   - check ionized calcium [**Hospital1 7**]
 replete as necessary
   - continue Morphine Sulfate 2-4 mg IV Q2H:PRN pain
   - appreciate surgery recs / GI recs
   - touch base with radiology re MRI to assess for pancreatic abscesses
   .
   * Acute on chronic renal failure
 Cr increased again but UOP is good
   (80-100cc/hr). DDx include ATN, pre-renal and AIN.
   - maintain UOP >30cc/hr
   - Continue to trend Cr
   - f/u repeat UA, manually inspect urine sediment for casts
   - Renally dose meds and avoid nephrotoxins
   - f/u renal consult , consider HD in the future
   - pt appears euvolemic despite acute on chronic renal failure, keep Is
   and Os even today
   .
   * DM
 -Hold home oral agents. Has been hyperglycemic on TPN. Other
   causes for hyperglycemia include pancreatitis and stress response in
   the setting of sepsis and acute illness.
   - continue insulin gtt
   .
   * Anemia
 Hct continues to drop.  Concern for hemolysis but
   haptoglobin elevated and peripheral smear essentially normal. The most
   likely cause is anemia of inflammation in the setting of acute disease.
   Hemorrhagic pancreatitis not seen on CT abd but no IV contrast given so
   may not be able to assess. Heme positive stools on admission
 may be
   due to gastritis, PUD. Other possible sources include diverticular
   bleed given known diverticulosis or colon cancer given h/o adenomas. No
   history of varices.  Also possibly related to stomach erosions seen on
   ERCP from OG trauma.
   - Follow Hct daily
   - IV PPI
   - Maintain active T+S
   - Repeat endoscopy in 8 weeks
   .
   * HTN
Noted to be more elevated when pt turned or sedation/fentanyl
   decreased. [**Month (only) 51**] be in response to pain. Holding atenolol in setting of
   renal insufficiency.
   - continue metoprolol 5mg IV q6H as it is hepatically and renally

He is currently intubated and on mechanical ventilation due to respiratory distress. The patient has anion gap metabolic acidosis, likely secondary to uremia, and is unable to compensate for his metabolic acidosis. The patient has gallstone pancreatitis and had two ERCP procedures with partial sphincterotomy and stent placement. Other conditions include diabetes mellitus, anemia, hypertension, and diverticular disease. The patient's prognosis appears to be poor.

1. Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP): The patient's febrile response, leukocytosis, and bilateral infiltrates on chest X-ray are concerning for VAP. This is a potential complication of mechanical ventilation.
2. Acute on chronic renal failure: The patient's elevated creatinine levels indicate worsening renal function. This could be due to ATN, pre-renal azotemia, or AIN. Prompt intervention is necessary to prevent further deterioration of renal function.

   Assessment and Plan
   Mr. [**Known lastname 9611**] is an 83M with hypercarbic respiratory failure, pancreatitis
   and renal failure.
   # Repiratory failure
 Pt has continued ventilator requirement. He has
   COPD which could have contributed to this respiratory distress. Pt has
   anion gap metabolic acidosis, likely secondary to uremia, he retains
   CO2 at baseline and is unable to breathe off his CO2 to compensate for
   his metabolic acidosis. Now febrile, with leukocytosis with bilateral
   infiltrates on CXR, concerning for VAP (see below). [**Month (only) 51**] also have
   atelectasis from increased abdominal pressure. Barriers to extubation
   include weakness and need to transition him from this metabolic
   acidosis to his baseline.
   - continue on AC vent settings as pt has elevated abdominal pressures
   (again) and metabolic acidosis that requires RR to compensate
   appropriately in setting of chronic resp acidosis from COPD.
   - cannot increase RR too much as pt is [**Name (NI) 9752**], and pt may stack
   breaths. Also, if inceasing RR too much, may end up just ventilating
   dead space.
   -Treatment of VAP (see below)
   - Continue sedation to make pt more comfortable
   - renal rec: no HD for now
   - consider trach
   .
   # COPD
 pt retains CO2 at baseline and is unable to breathe off his
   CO2 to compensate for his metabolic acidosis.
   - Correct metabolic acidosis as above
   - MDIs while on the vent
   .
   # FUO
 Pt meets SIRS criteria again for Temp, WBC, and RR. Unclear
   sources. Could be VAP. Cholangitis or continued obstruction is possible
   but not seen on ERCP.  Pancreatic necrosis is less likely given pt
   would appear much more ill and it was not noted on CT [**Last Name (un) **]. Pt may also
   have UTI in setting of foley, bacteremia or infected lines. Urine
   culture neg x2. Blood cx NGTD from [**Date range (1) 9733**]. Lines were changed. C.
   diff negative x2 and LENI negative for DVT. CT sinus ruled out
   sinusitis.  Endocarditis was not seen on TTE.  Osteo remains on the
   differential.
   - d/c IV Flagyl (C diff neg x3)
   - d/c VAP abx tomorrow after 8d course
   - continue empiric antifungal treatment with micafungin, consider d/c
   in 1-2d
   - F/u BCx
   - Maintain UOP>30 cc/hr, MAP> 60, monitor CVPs
   - f/u ID recs
   .
   * Gallstone Pancreatitis - s/p ERCP x2 which showed gallstone
   obstructive pancreatitis.  Pt had partial sphincterotomy with retained
   stone.  Had another ERCP [**2153-9-20**] with old stent removal/new stent
   placement with grossly distended abdomen after.  Abdominal exam showed
   continued distention after initial improvement after OGT placement.
   Pancreatitis improving. Calcium level improving.
   - Trend LFTs, amylase and lipase
   - continue zosyn, vanc and cipro as above
   - OGT in place for GI decompression
   - continue TPN (instead of TF) given increased abdominal distention,
   will consider transition to TF since pt has less OGT output now -> get
   him on IR schedule for Fri
   - check bladder pressures [**Hospital1 7**]
   - check ionized calcium [**Hospital1 7**]
 replete as necessary
   - continue Morphine Sulfate 2-4 mg IV Q2H:PRN pain
   - appreciate surgery recs / GI recs
   - touch base with radiology re MRI to assess for pancreatic abscesses
   .
   * Acute on chronic renal failure
 Cr increased again but UOP is good
   (80-100cc/hr). DDx include ATN, pre-renal and AIN.
   - maintain UOP >30cc/hr
   - Continue to trend Cr
   - f/u repeat UA, manually inspect urine sediment for casts
   - Renally dose meds and avoid nephrotoxins
   - f/u renal consult , consider HD in the future
   - pt appears euvolemic despite acute on chronic renal failure, keep Is
   and Os even today
   .
   * DM
 -Hold home oral agents. Has been hyperglycemic on TPN. Other
   causes for hyperglycemia include pancreatitis and stress response in
   the setting of sepsis and acute illness.
   - continue insulin gtt
   .
   * Anemia
 Hct continues to drop.  Concern for hemolysis but
   haptoglobin elevated and peripheral smear essentially normal. The most
   likely cause is anemia of inflammation in the setting of acute disease.
   Hemorrhagic pancreatitis not seen on CT abd but no IV contrast given so
   may not be able to assess. Heme positive stools on admission
 may be
   due to gastritis, PUD. Other possible sources include diverticular
   bleed given known diverticulosis or colon cancer given h/o adenomas. No
   history of varices.  Also possibly related to stomach erosions seen on
   ERCP from OG trauma.
   - Follow Hct daily
   - IV PPI
   - Maintain active T+S
   - Repeat endoscopy in 8 weeks
   .
   * HTN
Noted to be more elevated when pt turned or sedation/fentanyl
   decreased. [**Month (only) 51**] be in response to pain. Holding atenolol in setting of
   renal insufficiency.
   - continue metoprolol 5mg IV q6H as it is hepatically and renally
   cleared.
   - Address pain and monitor BP
   .
   * Goals of care: Patient is not improving, appear to have poor
   prognosis
   - update family on patient status

Summary:
The patient is an 83-year-old male with hypercarbic respiratory failure, pancreatitis, and renal failure. He is intubated and sedated, with a fever and leukocytosis, suggesting a possible hospital-acquired pneumonia (VAP). The patient also has COPD, metabolic acidosis, and elevated abdominal pressures. There is a history of gallstone pancreatitis, with an ERCP showing a retained stone. The patient has acute on chronic renal failure, with an increased creatinine level. Other conditions include diabetes mellitus, anemia, hypertension, and potential gastrointestinal bleeding. The patient's prognosis appears poor.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Hospital-acquired pneumonia (VAP): The patient's fever, leukocytosis, and bilateral infiltrates on chest X-ray indicate a possible infection. Immediate treatment is necessary to prevent further complications.
2. COPD exacerbation: The patient's history of COPD and difficulty in breathing may lead to an exacerbation of his chronic respiratory condition.
3. Pancreatitis complications: The patient has gallstone pancreatitis, which can lead to complications such as pancreatic necrosis or abscess formation.
4. Acute kidney injury: The patient's renal failure and elevated creatinine level suggest a risk of worsening kidney function, potentially requiring dialysis.
5. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's heme-positive stools and history of gastritis, PUD, diverticulosis, and colon cancer may indicate gastrointestinal

Summary:
The patient is an 83-year-old male with a history of pancreatitis, respiratory failure, renal failure, and fever of unknown origin (FUO). He has been admitted to the ICU and has undergone several interventions, including ERCP, antibiotics, and other medications. 

The patient's current vital signs include a temperature of 102.5°F (39.2°C), blood pressure ranging from 148/50-188/89 mmHg, heart rate of 84 bpm, respiratory rate of 26 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 97%. He is intubated and on mechanical ventilation.

The patient's physical examination reveals distant heart sounds, difficulty assessing lung bases, distended abdomen without guarding or rigidity, swollen testes, and 2+ hand edema. His mental status is poor, with eyes wide open and unresponsiveness to voice.

The patient's lab results show elevated white blood cell count, hemoglobin, and platelet count, but decreased hematocrit, creatinine, calcium, and magnesium levels. His liver function tests are slightly abnormal, with elevated alkaline phosphatase and aspartate transaminase. The amylase and lipase levels are significantly elevated, indicating ongoing pancreatic inflammation. Blood cultures have been negative, and there is no evidence of infection in the urine or catheter tip cultures. Imaging studies reveal new right lower lobe opacity, possibly due to atelectasis, effusion, plug, or infection

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an 83-year-old male with multiple medical conditions including hypercarbic respiratory failure, pancreatitis, and renal failure. The patient is intubated and on mechanical ventilation due to respiratory failure. He is also febrile with leukocytosis and bilateral infiltrates on chest X-ray, which raises concerns for ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP).

The patient has a history of COPD, which could contribute to his respiratory distress. He is retaining CO2 at baseline and unable to compensate for metabolic acidosis. The patient's current treatment includes antibiotics for suspected VAP, sedation to maintain comfort, and continuation of TPN due to increased abdominal pressures.

The patient's renal function is worsening, as indicated by an increase in creatinine levels. He has acute on chronic renal failure, and the differential diagnosis includes acute tubular necrosis (ATN), pre-renal azotemia, and acute interstitial nephritis (AIN). The plan is to maintain urine output above 30 cc/hr, monitor central venous pressures, and consult with a nephrologist.

The patient's blood glucose levels are elevated, possibly due to pancreatitis, stress response, and TPN. Insulin therapy is being continued to manage hyperglycemia.

The patient's anemia is likely due to anemia of inflammation in the setting of acute disease. Hemolysis is not supported by elevated haptoglobin and normal peripheral smear. Possible sources

Summary:
The patient is an 83-year-old male with multiple medical conditions including hypercarbic respiratory failure, pancreatitis, renal failure, COPD, sepsis, gallstone pancreatitis, anemia, diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and acute on chronic renal failure. The patient has been admitted to the ICU and is currently intubated and sedated. He is febrile with leukocytosis and bilateral infiltrates on chest X-ray, suggesting ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP). The patient also has elevated abdominal pressures, metabolic acidosis, and anion gap metabolic acidosis likely due to uremia. He has a history of gallstone pancreatitis and has undergone two ERCP procedures with partial improvement. The patient's renal function is deteriorating, and he requires renal consultation for potential dialysis. His blood glucose levels are uncontrolled, and his anemia is likely due to anemia of inflammation. His blood pressure is poorly controlled, and he requires continued monitoring and management.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP): The patient's clinical presentation suggests VAP, indicated by fever, leukocytosis, and bilateral infiltrates on chest X-ray. Appropriate treatment should be initiated promptly.
2. Acute kidney injury (AKI): The patient's renal function is deteriorating, as indicated by an increasing creatinine level. This may be due to acute tubular necrosis (ATN), pre-renal azot

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an 83-year-old male with sepsis, acute renal failure on chronic renal insufficiency (ACRI), acute respiratory failure, severe gallstone pancreatitis, profound metabolic acidosis, and hypocalcemia. The patient's condition is worsening, and potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP): The patient has been on mechanical ventilation and has developed high fevers and leukocytosis, indicating a possible infection. VAP is a common complication in patients receiving mechanical ventilation for more than 48 hours.

2. Acute kidney injury (AKI): The patient's renal function is declining, and he has acute on chronic renal insufficiency. AKI can lead to further deterioration of renal function and may require dialysis.

3. Sepsis: The patient has sepsis due to an infection, which can progress to septic shock and multiple organ dysfunction syndrome (MODS).

4. Complications of pancreatitis: The patient has severe gallstone pancreatitis, which can lead to pancreatic necrosis, pseudocysts, abscess formation, and biliary complications.

5. Metabolic disturbances: The patient has metabolic acidosis and hypocalcemia, which can lead to various complications such as cardiac arrhythmias, muscle weakness, and altered mental status.

6. Respiratory failure: The patient is experiencing acute respiratory failure, which may require prolonged mechanical ventilation and

   Assessment and Plan
   Mr. [**Known lastname 9611**] is an 83M with pancreatitis, respiratory failure, renal
   failure, and FUO.
   .
   # FUO
 Most likely related to severe pancreatitis.  No source of
   infection after full workup including cultures, TTE, CT sinus, line
   change. This could be VAP, but pt has been on vanc, zosyn and cipro for
   about a week, and continues to have fevers.
   - d/c IV Flagyl (C diff neg x3)
   - d/c VAP abx tomorrow after 8d course
   - continue empiric antifungal treatment with micafungin, consider d/c
   in 1-2d
   - F/u BCx
   - Maintain UOP>30 cc/hr, MAP> 60, monitor CVPs
   - f/u ID recs
   .
   # Repiratory failure
 Pt has continued ventilator requirement.
   Barriers to extubation include weakness and metabolic acidosis in the
   setting of uremia and poor mental status. Pt is off propofol currently.
   CXR revealed new LLL opacity, concerning for pleural effusion in the
   setting of acute on chronic renal failure.
   - continue on AC vent settings as pt is stable on the current setting
   - since pt has been on ventilator for over a week, no sign of
   extubation soon, will talk with family re trach and get trach consult
   today
   - continue to be off propofol
   - renal rec: no HD for now
   .
   # COPD
 pt retains CO2 at baseline and is unable to breathe off his
   CO2 to compensate for his metabolic acidosis. PIP significantly higher
   than plateau pressure, question if he has higher resistance due to COPD
   exacerbation.
   - MDIs while on the vent
   .
   * Gallstone Pancreatitis
 slowly improving. s/p ERCP x2 which showed
   gallstone obstructive pancreatitis.
   - Trend LFTs, amylase and lipase
   - peel off abx tomorrow
   - OGT in place for GI decompression, output decreasing
   - continue TPN (instead of TF) given increased abdominal distention,
   will consider transition to TF since pt has less OGT output now -> get

Summary:
The patient is an 83-year-old male with a history of pancreatitis, respiratory failure, renal failure, and fever of unknown origin (FUO). He is currently intubated and on mechanical ventilation due to respiratory failure. He has been diagnosed with gallstone pancreatitis and has undergone two ERCP procedures. The patient has been on various antibiotics for suspected ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) and catheter-related bloodstream infection (CRBI), but no source of infection has been identified. His urine output is good, and he is euvolemic despite acute on chronic renal failure. The patient's condition remains poor, and he has multiple medical complications that require ongoing management.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP): Despite being on appropriate antibiotics for VAP, the patient continues to have fevers, which may indicate persistent infection or antibiotic resistance.
2. Catheter-related bloodstream infection (CRBI): The patient's central lines should be monitored for signs of infection, and cultures should be obtained to rule out CRBI.
3. Acute kidney injury (AKI): The patient has acute on chronic renal failure, and his creatinine levels are increasing. He requires careful fluid management and monitoring of renal function.
4. Pancreatitis: The patient has gallstone pancreatitis, which is slowly improving. His pancreatic enzymes (amylase and lipase) should be trended, and he should be monitored for any complications related to pancre

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is an 83-year-old male with a history of pancreatitis, respiratory failure, renal failure, and fever of unknown origin (FUO). He is currently intubated and on mechanical ventilation. The patient has been treated for various infections, including pneumonia and catheter-related bloodstream infection, but no definitive source of infection has been identified. He has also been diagnosed with acute on chronic renal failure, anemia, diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and gallstone pancreatitis.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP): The patient's prolonged intubation and mechanical ventilation put him at risk for developing VAP. The healthcare team is monitoring for signs of infection and implementing appropriate preventive measures.
2. Renal failure: The patient has acute on chronic renal failure, which may worsen due to ongoing kidney injury. Close monitoring of renal function and consideration of dialysis may be necessary.
3. Pancreatitis: The patient has gallstone pancreatitis, which can lead to complications such as pancreatic necrosis or pseudocyst formation. Continued monitoring of pancreatic enzymes and imaging studies may be required.
4. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory condition may deteriorate further, potentially necessitating tracheostomy placement and long-term ventilation support.
5. Infection: Despite receiving broad-spectrum antibiotics, the patient continues to have fevers. Additional diagnostic tests and cultures may be needed to identify the underlying infection and guide appropriate treatment.
6.

Imaging studies reveal atelectasis and effusions on chest X-ray, and the patient's urine analysis shows trace leukocytes and 24 red blood cells. 

The patient's current medications include broad-spectrum antibiotics, insulin, antacids, diuretics, and pain management with dilaudid.

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an 83-year-old male with multiple medical complications. The patient's chief complaint includes gallstone pancreatitis, sepsis, acute on chronic renal failure, and acute respiratory failure. The patient is currently in the intensive care unit (ICU) and requires full ventilator support.

The patient's current assessment includes profound metabolic acidosis, hypocalcemia, abdominal distention/ileus, and a possible ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP). The patient also has ongoing fevers, leukocytosis, and declining renal function.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's current condition include:

1. Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS): The patient's respiratory failure and the need for full ventilator support indicate a high risk for developing ARDS. This condition is characterized by severe inflammation and fluid accumulation in the lungs, leading to impaired oxygenation.

2. Multiorgan dysfunction syndrome (MODS): The patient's critical illness and poor prognosis suggest a risk of MODS, which occurs when multiple organs fail due to systemic inflammation or infection.

3. Sepsis-induced cardiomyopathy: The patient's sepsis and hypotension may lead to sepsis-induced cardiomyopathy, a condition where the heart muscle becomes weakened and dysfunction due to systemic infection.

4. Acute kidney injury (AKI): The patient's declining renal function and acute on chronic renal failure indicate a risk of developing AKI. This

   Mr. [**Known lastname 9611**] is an 83M with pancreatitis, respiratory failure, renal
   failure, and FUO.
   .
   # FUO
 Most likely related to severe pancreatitis.  No source of
   infection after full workup including cultures, TTE, CT sinus, line
   change. Pt was on vanc, zosyn and cipro for 8 days for VAP. Pt
   continues to have fevers.
   - continue meropenem and vanc
   - continue empiric antifungal treatment with micafungin, consider d/c
   in a few days
   - continued monitoring and culture if spikes
   - F/u BCx and urine culture
   - tylenol for fever
   - Maintain UOP>30 cc/hr, MAP> 65, monitor CVPs
   - f/u ID recs
   .
   # Repiratory failure
 Pt has continued ventilator requirement.
   Barriers to extubation include weakness and metabolic acidosis in the
   setting of uremia and poor mental status. Pt is off propofol currently.
   CXR improved after lasix yesterday.
   - continue on AC vent settings as pt is stable on the current setting
   - tracheostomy today
   - I/O goal today is -500cc today
   - continue to be off propofol
   - renal recs: consider HD in [**2-27**] days
   - treat pt
s underlying COPD with MDIs
   .
   * Gallstone Pancreatitis
 slowly improving. s/p ERCP x2 which showed
   gallstone obstructive pancreatitis.  Pt has post-pyloric feeding tube
   in place since [**9-27**].
   - OGT output significantly slowed down,  but no feeding yet as pt
   continues to have some OGT output
   - continue to have OGT in place for GI decompression, output decreasing
   - continue TPN for now
   - repeat CT abd today, the last one was from [**9-24**]
   - dilaudid for pain control, and fentanyl bolus for pain as well
   - continue to trend LFTs, amylase and lipase
   - check bladder pressures daily
   - check ionized calcium daily
 replete as necessary
   .
   * Acute on chronic renal failure
 Renal following: thinking about HD
   in the next few days. Cr increased again but UOP is good. DDx include
   ATN, pre-renal and AIN. Urien eos neg x2.
   - HD line today
   - I/O goal today is -500cc
   - maintain UOP >30cc/hr
   - Continue to trend Cr
   - Renally dose meds and avoid nephrotoxins
   .
   * DM
 -Hold home oral agents. Has been hyperglycemic on TPN. Other
   causes for hyperglycemia include pancreatitis and stress response in
   the setting of sepsis and acute illness.
   - continue insulin gtt
   .
   * Anemia
 Hct stable. The most likely cause is anemia of inflammation
   in the setting of acute disease. Concern for hemolysis but haptoglobin
   elevated and peripheral smear essentially normal. Hemorrhagic
   pancreatitis not seen on CT abd. Heme positive stools on admission
   may be due to gastritis, PUD. Other possible sources include
   diverticular bleed given known diverticulosis or colon cancer given h/o
   adenomas. No history of varices.  Also possibly related to stomach
   erosions seen on ERCP from OG trauma.
   - Follow Hct daily
   - IV PPI
   - Maintain active T+S
   - Repeat endoscopy in 8 weeks
   .
   * HTN
Noted to be more elevated after propofol was off, could be
   secondary to pain. Holding atenolol in setting of renal insufficiency.
   - dilaudid for pain control
   - continue metoprolol 5mg IV q6H as it is hepatically and renally
   cleared.
   .
   * Goals of care: Patient is not improving, appear to have poor
   prognosis
   - update family on patient status

The patient is an 83-year-old male with a history of pancreatitis, respiratory failure, renal failure, and fever of unknown origin (FUO). He has been in the ICU for an extended period and is currently intubated, with no improvement in his condition. The patient has multiple comorbidities including gallstone pancreatitis, acute on chronic renal failure, diabetes mellitus, anemia, hypertension, and potential gastrointestinal bleeding.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Infection: The patient has been experiencing fevers despite being on antibiotics. The source of infection is still unknown, and the patient continues to have positive blood cultures pending. This suggests a high risk of ongoing or recurrent infection.
2. Respiratory Failure: The patient is still dependent on mechanical ventilation, indicating ongoing respiratory failure. His underlying COPD may contribute to this complication, and the presence of bilateral opacities on chest X-ray suggests possible effusions or fluid overload.
3. Renal Failure: The patient has acute on chronic renal failure, as indicated by rising creatinine levels. There is a need for further evaluation and potential hemodialysis to manage his renal function.
4. Pancreatitis: The patient has gallstone pancreatitis, which is slowly improving but still requires close monitoring. Ongoing pain management and consideration of further interventions like repeat CT abdomen may be necessary.
5. Anemia: The patient has stable hematocrit levels, but further investigation is needed to determine the cause of an

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an 83-year-old male with a chief complaint of gallstone pancreatitis, respiratory failure, and acute on chronic renal failure. The patient is currently in the ICU and has been diagnosed with sepsis, acute respiratory failure, severe gallstone pancreatitis, profound metabolic acidosis, and hypocalcemia.

The patient's condition is complicated by various factors. He has ongoing fevers and leukocytosis, abdominal distention/ileus, and declining renal function. The respiratory failure is multifactorial, including an inability to compensate for metabolic acidosis, renal failure, COPD, abdominal distention, and ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP). The patient requires full ventilator support and is not a candidate for weaning or spontaneous breathing trials.

The patient also has high fevers and profound leukocytosis, which have not been fully explained despite extensive infection evaluation. This may be related to severe pancreatitis or less likely drug fever. The patient remains in multiorgan dysfunction syndrome (MODS) with a poor prognosis.

In terms of management, the patient's current ventilator settings will be continued, and an tracheostomy is planned for today. The patient's ileus is slowly resolving, and post-pyloric feeding has been initiated. Trophic enteral feedings will be continued, and the possibility of additional recommendations from surgery will be considered. Total parenteral nutrition (TPN) will be continued due

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an 83-year-old male with a complex medical history including sepsis, acute kidney injury, acute respiratory failure, severe gallstone pancreatitis, profound metabolic acidosis, and hypocalcemia. The patient has been diagnosed with ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) and continues to have high fevers and leukocytosis. 

The patient's primary issues include metabolic acidosis (AGMA), respiratory failure, abdominal distention/ileus, ongoing fevers, leukocytosis, acute on chronic renal failure (CRF), gallstone pancreatitis, and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). The patient's respiratory failure is multifactorial, including an inability to compensate for metabolic acidosis, renal failure, distended abdomen, and VAP.

The patient's condition is described as in multiorgan dysfunction syndrome (MODS) with a poor prognosis. The plan includes continuing current ventilator settings, performing a tracheostomy, placing a peripherally inserted pulmonary artery catheter (PIPS), improving platelet count, and initiating hemodialysis (HD). 

The patient's ileus is slowly resolving, and an post-pyloric feeding tube has been placed. Total parenteral nutrition (TPN) is being continued due to poor nutritional status. The patient remains on insulin gtt for blood sugar control and is being treated for hypertension with labetalol. Pain management is also being addressed.

   - continue to be off propofol
   - renal recs: consider HD in [**2-27**] days
   - treat pt
s underlying COPD with MDIs
   .
   * Gallstone Pancreatitis
 slowly improving. s/p ERCP x2 which showed
   gallstone obstructive pancreatitis.  Pt has post-pyloric feeding tube
   in place since [**9-27**].
   - OGT output significantly slowed down,  can start TF today
   - continue TPN for now until goal TF is reached
   - repeat CT abd tomorrow, the last one was from [**9-24**]
   - dilaudid for pain control, and fentanyl bolus for pain as well
   - continue to trend LFTs, amylase and lipase
   - check bladder pressures daily
   - check ionized calcium daily
 replete as necessary
   .
   * Acute on chronic renal failure
 Renal following: thinking about HD
   in the next few days. Cr increased again but UOP is good. DDx include
   ATN, pre-renal and AIN. Urien eos neg x2.
   - HD line today
   - I/O goal today is -500cc
   - maintain UOP >30cc/hr
   - Continue to trend Cr
   - Renally dose meds and avoid nephrotoxins
   .
   * DM
 -Hold home oral agents. Has been hyperglycemic on TPN. Other
   causes for hyperglycemia include pancreatitis and stress response in
   the setting of sepsis and acute illness.
   - continue insulin gtt
   .
   * Anemia
 Hct stable. The most likely cause is anemia of inflammation
   in the setting of acute disease. Concern for hemolysis but haptoglobin
   elevated and peripheral smear essentially normal. Hemorrhagic
   pancreatitis not seen on CT abd. Heme positive stools on admission
   may be due to gastritis, PUD. Other possible sources include
   diverticular bleed given known diverticulosis or colon cancer given h/o
   adenomas. No history of varices.  Also possibly related to stomach
   erosions seen on ERCP from OG trauma.
   - Follow Hct daily
   - IV PPI
   - Maintain active T+S
   - Repeat endoscopy in 8 weeks
   .
   * HTN
Noted to be more elevated after propofol was off, could be
   secondary to pain. Also secondary to volume overload in the setting of
   acute on chronic renal failure. Holding atenolol in setting of renal
   insufficiency.
   - dilaudid for pain control
   - continue metoprolol 5mg IV q6H as it is hepatically and renally
   cleared.
   .
   * Goals of care: Patient is not improving, appear to have poor
   prognosis
   - update family on patient status

Summary:
The patient is an 83-year-old male with a history of pancreatitis, respiratory failure, renal failure, and fever of unknown origin (FUO). The patient has been intubated and placed on mechanical ventilation due to respiratory failure. He also has a tracheostomy in place. 

The patient's laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count, elevated creatinine, and elevated liver enzymes. Blood cultures, urine culture, and NG tube culture are negative. Imaging shows no significant changes in the chest X-ray.

The patient's current issues include respiratory failure, gallstone pancreatitis, acute on chronic renal failure, fever of unknown origin, diabetes mellitus, anemia, and hypertension. 

The treatment plan includes continuing mechanical ventilation, initiating hemodialysis, treating underlying COPD with MDIs, starting tube feeds, continuing total parenteral nutrition (TPN), monitoring liver function tests, amylase, and lipase. The patient will be monitored for potential complications such as ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP), deep vein thrombosis (DVT), stress ulcers, and autonomic nervous system dysfunction. 

The patient's prognosis is poor, and the family has been updated on the patient's status.

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is an 83-year-old male with a history of pancreatitis, respiratory failure, renal failure, and fever of unknown origin (FUO). He is currently intubated and on mechanical ventilation due to respiratory failure. The patient has a tracheostomy in place and is receiving total parenteral nutrition (TPN). His recent labs show elevated white blood cell count, elevated blood glucose levels, and elevated creatinine levels. Imaging shows no significant changes in the chest X-ray. The patient has been diagnosed with gallstone pancreatitis and has undergone two unsuccessful ERCP procedures. He also has acute on chronic renal failure, anemia of inflammation, diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and poor prognosis.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP): Given the patient's prolonged intubation and mechanical ventilation, there is an increased risk of developing VAP. Close monitoring of respiratory symptoms and cultures will be necessary.
2. Renal failure: The patient's elevated creatinine levels indicate worsening renal function. It is important to manage his fluid balance and adjust medications accordingly to avoid further renal deterioration.
3. Pancreatitis: The patient's pancreatitis may continue to progress and lead to complications such as necrosis or abscess formation. Monitoring of pancreatic enzymes and imaging studies may be required.
4. Infection: The patient's elevated white blood cell count and persistent fever suggest the possibility of an ongoing infection. Broad-spectrum antibiotics have been started,

   Assessment and Plan
   Mr. [**Known lastname 9611**] is an 83M with pancreatitis, respiratory failure, renal
   failure, and FUO.
   .
   # FUO
 Most likely related to severe pancreatitis.  No source of
   infection after full workup including cultures, TTE, CT sinus, line
   change. Pt was on vanc, zosyn and cipro for 8 days for VAP. Pt
   continues to have fevers.
   - continue meropenem as per ID
   - d/c micafungin and vanc
   - continued monitoring and culture if spikes
   - F/u BCx and urine culture
   - tylenol for fever
   - Maintain UOP>30 cc/hr, MAP> 65, monitor CVPs
   - f/u ID recs
   .
   # Repiratory failure
 Currently trached.   Pt has continued ventilator
   requirement. Barriers to extubation include weakness and metabolic
   acidosis in the setting of uremia and poor mental status. Pt is off
   propofol currently. CXR improved after lasix yesterday.
   - continue on AC vent settings as pt is stable on the current setting
   - I/O goal today is -500cc today
   - continue to be off propofol
   - renal recs: consider HD in [**2-27**] days
   - treat pt
s underlying COPD with MDIs
   .
   * Gallstone Pancreatitis
 slowly improving. s/p ERCP x2 which showed
   gallstone obstructive pancreatitis.  Pt has post-pyloric feeding tube
   in place since [**9-27**].  Clinically, patient is not improving much.
   - OGT output significantly slowed down,  can start TF today
   - continue TPN for now until goal TF is reached
   - consider repeat CT abd monday, the last one was from [**9-24**]
   - dilaudid for pain control, and fentanyl bolus for pain as well
   - continue to trend LFTs, amylase and lipase
   - check bladder pressures daily
   - check ionized calcium daily
 replete as necessary
   .
   * Acute on chronic renal failure
 Renal following: thinking about HD
   in the next few days. Cr increased again but UOP is good. DDx include
   ATN, pre-renal and AIN. Urine eos neg x2.
   - HD first session today
   - I/O goal today is -500cc
   - maintain UOP >30cc/hr
   - Continue to trend Cr
   - Renally dose meds and avoid nephrotoxins
   .
   * DM
 -Hold home oral agents. Has been hyperglycemic on TPN. Other
   causes for hyperglycemia include pancreatitis and stress response in
   the setting of sepsis and acute illness.
   - continue insulin gtt
   .
   * Anemia
 Hct stable. The most likely cause is anemia of inflammation
   in the setting of acute disease. Concern for hemolysis but haptoglobin
   elevated and peripheral smear essentially normal. Hemorrhagic
   pancreatitis not seen on CT abd. Heme positive stools on admission
   may be due to gastritis, PUD. Other possible sources include
   diverticular bleed given known diverticulosis or colon cancer given h/o
   adenomas. No history of varices.  Also possibly related to stomach
   erosions seen on ERCP from OG trauma.
   - Follow Hct daily
   - IV PPI
   - Maintain active T+S
   - Repeat endoscopy in 8 weeks
   .
   * HTN
Noted to be more elevated after propofol was off, could be
   secondary to pain. Also secondary to volume overload in the setting of
   acute on chronic renal failure. Holding atenolol in setting of renal
   insufficiency.
   - dilaudid for pain control
   - continue metoprolol 5mg IV q6H as it is hepatically and renally
   cleared.
   .
   * Goals of care: Patient is not improving, appear to have poor
   prognosis
   - update family on patient status

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is an 83-year-old male with a diagnosis of pancreatitis, respiratory failure, renal failure, and fever of unknown origin (FUO). He has been admitted to the ICU and is currently on mechanical ventilation through a tracheostomy tube. The patient's condition remains stable but has not shown significant improvement. 

The patient has a history of gallstone pancreatitis and has undergone two ERCP procedures. He also has underlying COPD and is being treated with MDIs. His renal function is compromised, and he is undergoing hemodialysis (HD) to manage his electrolyte imbalances and fluid overload. 

The patient's fever persists despite broad-spectrum antibiotics, indicating a possible ongoing infection. Laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count and C-reactive protein levels, suggesting an inflammatory response. 

The patient is receiving total parenteral nutrition (TPN) and is being gradually introduced to tube feeds. His blood glucose levels are being monitored and managed with insulin infusions. 

Other medical conditions present include acute on chronic renal failure, diabetes mellitus, anemia, and hypertension. 

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP): Due to the patient's prolonged mechanical ventilation, there is an increased risk of developing VAP. 
2. Infection: The patient's persistent fever and elevated inflammatory markers suggest the possibility of an ongoing infection, which could be related to his pancreatitis or another source.

The infectious disease (ID) team recommends continuing with Meropenem for at least 72 hours before making any further changes to the antibiotic regimen.

The patient has undergone several interventions, including a percutaneous tracheostomy, which was done on September 28th. He is currently on mechanical ventilation and is expected to remain intubated due to weakness and metabolic acidosis related to uremia and poor mental status.

The patient has gallstone pancreatitis and is slowly improving from a laboratory standpoint. He has had two ERCP procedures, which confirmed gallstone obstructive pancreatitis. The patient has a post-pyloric feeding tube in place since September 27th, but there were concerns about possible aspiration of tube feeds. Therefore, tube feeds were stopped at 1 AM.

The patient's condition is slowly improving, but he continues to have daily high fevers. His renal function is deteriorating, as indicated by an increasing creatinine level. He is also experiencing anemia, hyperglycemia, and hypertension.

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory failure is a significant concern. He is currently on mechanical ventilation and requires further assessment of his respiratory status. Barriers to extubation include weakness, metabolic acidosis in the setting of uremia, and poor mental status.
2. Fever of Unknown Origin (FUO): Despite full workup including cultures, TTE, CT sinus, and line change, no source of infection has been identified. The patient continues to have daily high fevers, indicating ongoing inflammation or infection.

The patient's laboratory results indicate elevated white blood cell count, low hemoglobin, high platelet count, elevated creatinine levels, and abnormal liver function tests.

3. Kidney Injury: The patient's acute renal failure and elevated creatinine levels indicate a risk of kidney injury. This could be due to factors such as sepsis or complications from hemodialysis.

 Currently s/p tracheostomy ([**9-28**]).  Pt has

   - continue to be off propofol

s underlying COPD with MDIs

 slowly improving from the laboratory
   standpoint, but clinically pt hasn
t made much progress. s/p ERCP x2
   which showed gallstone obstructive pancreatitis.  Pt has post-pyloric
   feeding tube in place since [**9-27**].  Concern existed about possible
   aspiration of tube feeds.
   - try to re-initiate TF today, monitor OG tube output
   - continue TPN
   - consider repeat CT abd monday, the last one was from [**9-24**]
   - dilaudid for pain control, and fentanyl bolus prn for pain as well
   - continue to trend LFTs, amylase and lipase
   - check bladder pressures daily, currently < 15
   - check ionized calcium daily
 replete as necessary
   .
   .# FUO
 Most likely related to severe pancreatitis.  No source of
   infection after full workup including cultures, TTE, CT sinus, line
   change. Pt was on vanc, zosyn and cipro for 8 days for VAP. Pt
   continues to have daily high fevers.
   - consult ID concerning abx regimen in the setting of increasing WBC
   - continue treatment and monitoring as above for pancreatitis
   - F/u BCx and urine culture

   - f/u ID recs
   - Maintain MAP> 65, monitor CVPs
   * Acute on chronic renal failure
 Renal following. Cr increased again
   but UOP is good. DDx include ATN, pre-renal and AIN. Urine eos neg x2.
   - HD first session yesterday
   - I/O goal today is -2L
   - Continue to trend Cr
   - dose meds per HD protocol
   .

 -Hold home oral agents. Has been hyperglycemic on TPN. Other
   causes for hyperglycemia include pancreatitis and stress response in
   the setting of sepsis and acute illness.
   - continue insulin gtt
   .
   * Anemia
 Hct stable. The most likely cause is anemia of inflammation
   in the setting of acute disease. Concern for hemolysis but haptoglobin
   elevated and peripheral smear essentially normal. Hemorrhagic
   pancreatitis not seen on CT abd. Heme positive stools on admission
   may be due to gastritis, PUD. Other possible sources include
   diverticular bleed given known diverticulosis or colon cancer given h/o
   adenomas. No history of varices.  Also possibly related to stomach
   erosions seen on ERCP from OG trauma.
   - Follow Hct daily
   - IV PPI
   - Repeat endoscopy in 8 weeks
   .
   * HTN
Noted to be more elevated after propofol was off, could be
   secondary to pain. Also secondary to volume overload in the setting of
   acute on chronic renal failure. Holding atenolol in setting of renal
   insufficiency.
   - HD today
   - dilaudid for pain control
   - continue metoprolol 5mg IV q6H as it is hepatically and renally
   cleared.
   .

   prognosis
   - update family on patient status

Summary:
The patient is an 83-year-old male with a history of pancreatitis, respiratory failure, renal failure, and fever of unknown origin (FUO). He is currently intubated and on mechanical ventilation due to respiratory failure. The patient has been diagnosed with gallstone pancreatitis and has undergone two ERCP procedures. He has a post-pyloric feeding tube in place and is receiving total parenteral nutrition (TPN) due to concerns about aspiration.

The patient's condition is complicated by several factors:
1. Respiratory failure: The patient requires ongoing ventilatory support, and there are concerns about his ability to wean off the ventilator due to weakness and metabolic acidosis.
2. Renal failure: The patient has acute on chronic renal failure, and his creatinine levels have been rising despite hemodialysis sessions. The underlying cause of renal failure is unclear and may be related to acute tubular necrosis (ATN), pre-renal azotemia, or allergic interstitial nephritis (AIN).
3. Fever of unknown origin (FUO): Despite extensive workup including cultures, transesophageal echocardiogram (TTE), CT scan of the sinuses, and line changes, no source of infection has been identified. The patient continues to have daily high fevers.
4. Anemia: The patient has a stable hemoglobin level, but further evaluation is needed to determine the cause. Possible causes include anemia of inflammation, hemolysis

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an 83-year-old male with a history of pancreatitis, respiratory failure, renal failure, and fever of unknown origin (FUO). The patient has been admitted to the ICU and has undergone several interventions and treatments.

The patient's current vital signs include a temperature of 104.1 F, heart rate of 111 bpm, blood pressure of 119/60 mmHg, respiratory rate of 35 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 94%. The patient is intubated and on mechanical ventilation with a tidal volume of 480 mL, respiratory rate set at 26 breaths per minute, positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) of 10 cmH2O, and fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) of 40%. The patient's arterial blood gas (ABG) analysis shows a pH of 7.43, PaCO2 of 29 mmHg, PaO2 of 228 mmHg, and HCO3- of 91 mEq/L.

The patient's physical examination reveals distant heart sounds, a regular rhythm, no murmurs, distended abdomen with guarding, hypoactive bowel sounds, and swollen scrotum. Laboratory results indicate elevated white blood cell count (WBC) of 33.9 K/uL, hemoglobin (Hb) of 7.5 g/dL, hematocrit (Hct) of 25.3%, platelet count (Plt) of 532 K/uL, blood urea nitrogen (BUN) of 46 mg/dL, creatinine (Cr) of 4.1 mg/dL, glucose of 126 mg/dL, sodium (Na+) of 111 mg/dL, potassium (K+) of 4.1 mg/dL, chloride (Cl-) of 19 mEq/L, calcium (Ca++) of 7.4 mg/dL, magnesium (Mg++) of 2.3 mg/dL, phosphorus (PO4) of 5.4 mg/dL, and total bilirubin (T Bili) of 0.9 mg/dL.

Imaging studies show no interval change on chest X-ray (CXR). The patient has a history of gallstone pancreatitis and has undergone two endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) procedures. A post-pyloric feeding tube has been placed, and there are concerns about possible aspiration of tube feeds.

The patient is being treated for fever of unknown origin (FUO) with broad-spectrum antibiotics, including vancomycin, meropenem, and ciprofloxacin. The patient also has acute on chronic renal failure, and the first hemodialysis (HD) session was conducted yesterday. The patient's diabetes mellitus (DM) is currently being managed with insulin g

   the setting of sepsis and acute illness.

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is an 83-year-old male with severe pancreatitis, respiratory failure, renal failure on hemodialysis, and fever of unknown origin (FUO). He has been admitted to the ICU and is currently intubated and on mechanical ventilation. His vital signs show a high fever, tachycardia, and low blood pressure. Laboratory results indicate leukocytosis, elevated liver enzymes, and impaired renal function. Imaging studies reveal no significant changes in the lungs. The patient has been treated with antibiotics for suspected ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) but continues to have daily high fevers. He also has anemia, hyperglycemia, and hypertension. The goals of care are to update the family on the patient's status and provide comfort measures.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Infection: The patient's high fever and leukocytosis suggest a possible ongoing infection. Despite receiving antibiotics, he has not shown improvement. There is a concern for hospital-acquired infections, including VAP or bloodstream infection.
2. Respiratory Failure: The patient's continued need for mechanical ventilation indicates severe respiratory failure. There may be a risk of ventilator-associated complications such as barotrauma, ventilator-associated pneumonia, or tension pneumothorax.
3. Renal Failure: The patient's impaired renal function requires ongoing hemodialysis. Complications associated with renal failure include fluid overload, electrolyte imbalances, and uremic symptoms.
4. Pan

Summary:
The patient is an 83-year-old male with severe pancreatitis and multiple comorbidities including respiratory failure, renal failure, hypernatremia, fever of unknown origin (FUO), acute on chronic renal failure, atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response (AFib with RVR), diabetes mellitus (DM), anemia, and hypertension (HTN).

The patient's medical history includes COPD, diverticulosis, adenomas, and gallstone pancreatitis. He has been admitted to the ICU for severe pancreatitis and has undergone an ERCP procedure. The patient's current vital signs include a temperature of 102.6°F (39.2°C), blood pressure in the low 80s, heart rate of 79-150 bpm, respiratory rate of 22-37 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 97%.

The patient is currently on multiple medications including pantoprazole, metoprolol, heparin, dilaudid, and insulin. He is also receiving total parenteral nutrition (TPN) and post-pyloric tube feedings.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count, elevated blood urea nitrogen (BUN), elevated creatinine, low albumin, elevated lactate dehydrogenase (LDH), and abnormal electrolyte levels.

The patient's imaging studies reveal volume overload but show improvement after dialysis.

The patient's goals of care include updating the family on patient status

   Assessment and Plan
   Mr. [**Known lastname 9611**] is an 83M with severe pancreatitis and daily fevers,
   respiratory failure, renal failure on HD
   .
   # Repiratory failure
 Currently s/p tracheostomy ([**9-28**]).  Pt has
   continued ventilator requirement. Barriers to extubation include
   weakness and metabolic acidosis in the setting of uremia and poor
   mental status. Pt is off propofol currently. CXR shows improvement on
   volume overload. Respiratory rate is 38-39 this AM, possibly as pt has
   a increased drive to ventilate as he has metabolic acidosis, and as
   patient has been fevers.
   - continue current ventilator setting as pt appears comfortable.
   - first HD session began [**9-29**], HD currently held for stable Cr, CXR
   remarkably look better today even though pt had no HD session yesterday
   - treat pt
s underlying COPD with MDIs, held albuterol this AM  for
   Afib
   - continue to be off propofol
   .
   * Gallstone Pancreatitis
 CT abd unchanged, still has massive
   inflammation in the abdomen, no evidence of pancreatic necrosis or
   presence of pseudocysts but the scan had no IV contrast. Pt is s/p ERCP
   x2 which showed gallstone obstructive pancreatitis.  Pt has
   post-pyloric feeding tube in place since [**9-27**].
   - continue TF, consult surgery regarding advancing TF
   - continue TPN
   - dilaudid for pain control, and fentanyl bolus prn for pain as well
   - continue to trend LFTs, amylase and lipase
   - check bladder pressures daily, currently < 15
   - check ionized calcium daily
 replete as necessary
   .
   .# FUO
 Most likely related to severe pancreatitis.  No source of
   infection after full workup including cultures, TTE, CT sinus, line
   change. Pt was on vanc, zosyn and cipro for 8 days for VAP. Also, was
   on meropenem for meropenem. Pt continues to have daily high fevers.
   - All abx were peeled off on [**10-1**]
   - F/u BCx and sputum culture
   - tylenol for fever
   - cool pt down when he has fevers, with cooling blankets, ice packs,
   fans etc
   - Maintain MAP> 65, monitor CVPs
   - continue treatment and monitoring as above for pancreatitis
   * Acute on chronic renal failure
 Renal following. Cr is stable, UOP
   is good. DDx include ATN, pre-renal and AIN. Urine eos neg x2.
   - HD first session [**9-29**], HD held as pt appears to be stable
   - Continue to trend Cr
   - dose meds per HD protocol
   .
   * Hypernatremia
 Most likely secondary to TPN or TF.
   - free water deficit was calculated to be 3.8L. Would give free water
   boluses.
    - PM lytes
   .
   * Afib with RVR
  Most likely secondary to the fevers, pain and
   inflammatory state. TSH pending but previously has been normal.
   - maintain good pain control with dilaudid
   - discontinue IV metoprolol as pt does not seem to respond to it well
   - discontinue dilt gtt as blood pressure went down on the gtt
   - start dilt 30mg QID
   - no anticoagulation for now given only one episode in the setting of
   acute illness
   - f/u TSH  --2.2 (normal)
   .
   * DM
 Blood sugar has been running at low 100s, and pt was not Hold
   home oral agents. Has been hyperglycemic on TPN. Other causes for
   hyperglycemia include pancreatitis and stress response in the setting
   of sepsis and acute illness.
   - discontinue insulin gtt
   - start insulin ss
   .
   * Anemia
 Hct slowly trending down. The most likely cause is anemia of
   inflammation in the setting of acute disease. Concern for hemolysis but
   haptoglobin elevated and peripheral smear essentially normal.
   Hemorrhagic pancreatitis not seen on CT abd. Heme positive stools on
   admission
 may be due to gastritis, PUD. Other possible sources
   include diverticular bleed given known diverticulosis or colon cancer
   given h/o adenomas. No history of varices.  Also possibly related to
   stomach erosions seen on ERCP from OG trauma.  Could also be attributed
   to dialysis.
   - Follow Hct daily
   - 1u pRBC today
   - IV PPI
   .
   * HTN
 better controlled now. Initially noted to be more elevated
   after propofol was off, could be secondary to pain. Also secondary to
   volume overload in the setting of acute on chronic renal failure.

Summary:
The patient is an 83-year-old male with severe pancreatitis, respiratory failure, and renal failure on hemodialysis (HD). He has been experiencing daily fevers, metabolic acidosis, and poor mental status. The patient's respiratory rate is high due to an increased drive to ventilate as he has metabolic acidosis and fever. His CXR shows improvement in volume overload. The patient's gallstone pancreatitis has been treated with ERCP, and he has a post-pyloric feeding tube in place. His fever of unknown origin (FUO) is most likely related to severe pancreatitis, and all antibiotics have been discontinued. The patient's acute on chronic renal failure is being managed with HD, and his hypernatremia is likely secondary to TPN or TF. He experienced atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response (AFib with RVR) and was treated with IV medications. The patient's diabetes mellitus (DM) is managed with insulin. Anemia of inflammation is suspected, and the patient may require a blood transfusion. His hypertension (HTN) is better controlled now, but initially, it was elevated after stopping propofol, which could be secondary to pain. The patient's goals of care include updating the family on his status. The patient has multiple lines, including an arterial line, multi-lumen line, dialysis catheter, tracheostomy, HD line, post-pyloric feeding tube, and OGT. Pro

   Mr. [**Known lastname 9611**] is an 83M with severe pancreatitis and daily fevers,
   respiratory failure, renal failure on HD
   .
   # Repiratory failure
 Currently s/p tracheostomy ([**9-28**]).  Pt has
   continued ventilator requirement. Barriers to extubation include
   weakness and metabolic acidosis in the setting of uremia and poor
   mental status. Pt is off propofol currently. Pt also has pleural
   effusion. Respiratory rate higher than the set rate, possibly as pt has
   a increased drive to ventilate as he has metabolic acidosis, and as
   patient has been fevers.  Ventilator setting was changed to PS this AM,
   currently at 16/10
   - continue current ventilator PS setting as pt appears comfortable,
   continue to monitor, get ABG on the new setting
   - first HD session began [**9-29**], HD currently held for stable Cr, CXR
   remarkably look better today even though pt had no HD session yesterday
   - per renal, IV lasix 40mg TID
   - treat pt
s underlying COPD with MDIs, held albuterol this AM  for
   Afib
   - continue to be off propofol
   .
   * Gallstone Pancreatitis
 CT abd unchanged, still has massive
   inflammation in the abdomen, no evidence of pancreatic necrosis or
   presence of pseudocysts but the scan had no IV contrast. Pt is s/p ERCP
   x2 which showed gallstone obstructive pancreatitis.  Pt has
   post-pyloric feeding tube in place since [**9-27**].
   - continue TF, goal rate 40cc/hr
   - continue TPN until TF running at 40cc/hr
   - dilaudid for pain control, and fentanyl bolus prn for pain as well
   - continue to trend LFTs, amylase and lipase
   - check bladder pressures daily, currently < 15
   - check ionized calcium daily
 replete as necessary
   .
   .# FUO
 Most likely related to severe pancreatitis.  No source of
   infection after full workup including cultures, TTE, CT sinus, line
   change. Pt was on vanc, zosyn and cipro for 8 days for VAP. Also, was
   on meropenem x 72hrs for meropenem. Pt continues to have daily high
   fevers.
   - All abx were peeled off on [**10-1**]
   - F/u BCx, urine culture and sputum culture
   - tylenol for fever
   - cool pt down when he has fevers, with cooling blankets, ice packs,
   fans etc
   - Maintain MAP> 65, monitor CVPs
   - continue treatment and monitoring as above for pancreatitis
   * Acute on chronic renal failure
 Renal following. Cr is stable, UOP
   is good. DDx include ATN, pre-renal and AIN. Urine eos neg x2.
   - HD first session [**9-29**], HD held as pt appears to be stable
   - per renal, lasix 40mg IV TID
   - Continue to trend Cr
   - dose meds renally or per HD protocol
   .
   * Hypernatremia
 Resolved s/p 1L free water (250cc boluses Q6H)
   yesterday.  Most likely secondary to TPN or TF or insensible loss from
   fevers.
   - continue to monitor
   .
   * Afib with RVR
  Most likely secondary to the fevers, pain and
   inflammatory state. discontinued IV metoprolol as pt did not seem to
   respond to it well. started dilt 30mg QID.
   - continue dilt 30mg QID, consider switching to metoprolol later as BB
   has more cardioprotective effect
   - maintain good pain control with dilaudid
   - no anticoagulation for now given only one episode in the setting of
   acute illness
   .
   * DM
Has been hyperglycemic on TPN. Other causes for hyperglycemia
   include pancreatitis and stress response in the setting of sepsis and
   acute illness.  Discontinued insulin gtt and started insulin ss on [**10-2**]
   (fixed glargine 24u qhs+ISS)
   - continue sc insulin
   - monitor closely when d/c TPN
   .
   * Anemia
 s/p 1u pRBC yesterday with little Hct response from 23.7 to
   23.8 s/p transfusion. The most likely cause is anemia of inflammation
   in the setting of acute disease. Concern for hemolysis but haptoglobin
   elevated and peripheral smear essentially normal. Hemorrhagic
   pancreatitis not seen on CT abd. Heme positive stools on admission
   may be due to gastritis, PUD. Other possible sources include
   diverticular bleed given known diverticulosis or colon cancer given h/o
   adenomas. No history of varices.  Also possibly related to stomach
   erosions seen on ERCP from OG trauma.
   - check Hct again this PM
   - consider another unit pRBC
   - IV PPI
   - consider EPO
   .
   * HTN
 better controlled now. Initially noted to be more elevated
   after propofol was off, could be secondary to pain. Also secondary to
   volume overload in the setting of acute on chronic renal failure.
   Holding atenolol in setting of renal insufficiency.
   - diltiazem 30mg QID started today
   - HD per renal
   - dilaudid for pain control as BP worsens with pain
   .
   * Agitation/anxiety: Pt was teary this am.
   - started on seroquel
   .

The patient's imaging shows a chest X-ray indicating volume overload.

Based on the information provided in the progress note, the patient is an 83-year-old male with severe pancreatitis, respiratory failure, renal failure on HD, and a history of COPD, gallstone pancreatitis, fever of unknown origin (FUO), acute on chronic renal failure, hypernatremia, atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response (AFib/RVR), diabetes mellitus (DM), anemia, and hypertension.

The patient has been admitted to the ICU and is currently receiving various treatments and interventions. The plan includes continuing current ventilator settings, holding off HD session, treating underlying COPD with MDIs, being off propofol, maintaining good pain control with dilaudid, checking bladder pressures daily, and repleting ionized calcium as necessary.

Additionally, the patient's fever is being managed with cooling blankets, ice packs, and fans. The renal failure is being treated with IV lasix 40mg TID, and the hypernatremia is being managed by continuing to monitor and providing free water. The AFib/RVR is being treated with diltiazem 30mg QID.

The patient's DM is being managed by discontinuing insulin gtt and starting sc insulin (fixed glargine 24u qhs+ISS). The anemia is being investigated, and the patient is scheduled for a blood transfusion. The hypertension is being managed with diltiazem 30mg QID and consideration of switching to met

   Mr. [**Known lastname 9611**] is an 83M with severe pancreatitis and daily fevers,
   respiratory failure, renal failure on HD
   .
   # Repiratory failure
 Currently s/p tracheostomy ([**9-28**]).  Pt has
   continued ventilator requirement. Barriers to extubation include
   weakness and metabolic acidosis in the setting of uremia and poor
   mental status. Pt is off propofol currently. Pt also has pleural
   effusion. Respiratory rate higher than the set rate, possibly as pt has
   a increased drive to ventilate as he has metabolic acidosis, and as
   patient has been fevers.
   - continue current ventilator setting as pt appears comfortable.
   - first HD session began [**9-29**], HD currently held for stable Cr, CXR
   remarkably look better today even though pt had no HD session yesterday
   - per renal, IV lasix 40mg TID
   - treat pt
s underlying COPD with MDIs, held albuterol this AM  for
   Afib
   - continue to be off propofol
   .
   * Gallstone Pancreatitis
 CT abd unchanged, still has massive
   inflammation in the abdomen, no evidence of pancreatic necrosis or
   presence of pseudocysts but the scan had no IV contrast. Pt is s/p ERCP
   x2 which showed gallstone obstructive pancreatitis.  Pt has
   post-pyloric feeding tube in place since [**9-27**].
   - continue TF at 40cc/hr
   - continue TPN until TF running at 40cc/hr
   - dilaudid for pain control, and fentanyl bolus prn for pain as well
   - continue to trend LFTs, amylase and lipase
   - check bladder pressures daily, currently < 15
   - check ionized calcium daily
 replete as necessary
   .
   .# FUO
 Most likely related to severe pancreatitis.  No source of
   infection after full workup including cultures, TTE, CT sinus, line
   change. Pt was on vanc, zosyn and cipro for 8 days for VAP. Also, was
   on meropenem x 72hrs for meropenem. Pt continues to have daily high
   fevers.
   - All abx were peeled off on [**10-1**]
   - F/u BCx, urine culture and sputum culture
   - tylenol for fever
   - cool pt down when he has fevers, with cooling blankets, ice packs,
   fans etc
   - Maintain MAP> 65, monitor CVPs
   - continue treatment and monitoring as above for pancreatitis
   * Acute on chronic renal failure
 Renal following. Cr is stable, UOP
   is good. DDx include ATN, pre-renal and AIN. Urine eos neg x2.
   - HD first session [**9-29**], HD held as pt appears to be stable
   - per renal, lasix 40mg IV TID
   - Continue to trend Cr
   - dose meds renally or per HD protocol
   .
   * Hypernatremia
 Most likely secondary to TPN or TF or insensible loss
   from fevers. s/p 1L free water (250cc boluses Q6H) yesterday
   - continue to monitor
   .
   * Afib with RVR
  Most likely secondary to the fevers, pain and
   inflammatory state. discontinued IV metoprolol as pt did not seem to
   respond to it well. started dilt 30mg QID.
   - continue dilt 30mg QID, consider switching to metoprolol later as BB
   has more cardioprotective effect
   - maintain good pain control with dilaudid
   - no anticoagulation for now given only one episode in the setting of
   acute illness
   .
   * DM
Has been hyperglycemic on TPN. Other causes for hyperglycemia
   include pancreatitis and stress response in the setting of sepsis and
   acute illness.  Discontinued insulin gtt and started insulin ss on [**10-2**]
   (fixed glargine 24u qhs+ISS)
   - continue sc insulin
   .
   * Anemia
 s/p 1u pRBC yesterday. The most likely cause is anemia of
   inflammation in the setting of acute disease. Concern for hemolysis but
   haptoglobin elevated and peripheral smear essentially normal.
   Hemorrhagic pancreatitis not seen on CT abd. Heme positive stools on
   admission
 may be due to gastritis, PUD. Other possible sources
   include diverticular bleed given known diverticulosis or colon cancer
   given h/o adenomas. No history of varices.  Also possibly related to
   stomach erosions seen on ERCP from OG trauma.
   - Follow Hct daily
   - IV PPI
   .
   * HTN
 better controlled now. Initially noted to be more elevated
   after propofol was off, could be secondary to pain. Also secondary to
   volume overload in the setting of acute on chronic renal failure.
   Holding atenolol in setting of renal insufficiency.
   - diltiazem 30mg QID started today
   - HD per renal
   - dilaudid for pain control
   .
