   Mr. [**Known lastname 9611**] is an 83M with pancreatitis, with respiratory failure, renal
   failure and now with sepsis.
   .
   # Respiratory failure
 currently s/p tracheostomy ([**9-28**]) and right
   sided thoracentesis ([**10-9**]). Pleural effusion rapidly re-accumulated in
   right lung after throacentesis, the effect was not durable.  The
   respiratory failure is likely secondary to volume overload in the
   setting of acute renal failure and abdominal distention impeding lung
   expansion.  Sputum cx grew klebsiella. Also has metabolic acidosis
   making it difficult to go off ventilator. Was briefly weaned off
   ventilator yesterday, but back on bc dyspneic.
   - currently on AC, tolerated PS yesterday, and periods of time with PMV
   as well, patient has been getting subjectively short of breath with PMV
   in place, however he was able to maintain his oxygen saturation without
   any increase in RR
   - sputum cultures => klebsiella, on cefepime per ID
   - sputum gram stain from [**10-20**] also shows GNR
   - treat pt
s underlying COPD with MDIs, incl albuterol
   - patient currently volume overloaded with almost no urine output, only
   93cc in past 24 hours, and he has been unable to tolerate CVVH to this
   point, volume overload likely contributing to poor respiratory status
   .
   # Sepsis: had lines and catheters changed and antibiotics continued in
   effort to treat possible catheter related gram positive bacteremia.
   Cath tip growing yeast, presumptively not c. albicans.  Pt has slight
   improvement in leukocytosis, afebrile overnight.  Other sources include
   urine, which grew yeasts, sputum which grew pansensitive klebsiella,
   and stool as pt had history of diarrhea.
   - continues on neo for BP support, will continue to down titrate and
   BP
s will allow, not on CVVH he is able to be weaned from pressors
   - as per ID rec, started micafungin for yeast in catheter tip cx. Blood
   cultures from [**10-16**] have been finalized as negative, per ID will
   complete a [**8-3**] day course.
   - pan-sensitive Klebsiella in sputum from [**10-13**], continue cefepime for
   additional GNR coverage.
   - dose vanc by level, level this morning was 19.6 with last dose on
   [**2153-10-20**], will recheck level in the morning
   - follow lactate
   - maintain goal MAP>65, CVP>10, ScvO2>70% with pressors if needed
   .
   # Acute on chronic renal failure Renal following. Creat worsening.
   Diff includes ATN, pre-renal and AIN. Urine eos neg x2.  He has very
   poor urine output.
   - difficuly tolerating  CVVH due to hypotension, ectopy and clotting in
   machine
   - as per renal will hold off in CVVH for now, given his inability to
   tolerate it and he has no urgent indication, will continue to monitor
   and renal is continuing to follow
   - patient remains volume overloaded with very low urine output,
   electrolyte management with CVVH
   .
   # Gallstone Pancreatitis
 repeat CT abd without IV contrast unchanged,
   still has massive inflammation in the abdomen, no evidence of
   pancreatic necrosis or presence of pseudocysts. Has had post-pyloric
   feeding tube in place since [**9-27**].
   - patient currently tolerating tube feeds with erythromycin
   - OGT still in place
   - CT abd/pelvis with severe unchanged pancreatitis
   - continue erythromycin
   - continue to trend LFTs, lipase as normalized
   - check ionized calcium daily
 replete as necessary
   .
   # DM
 pt has type II DM. Other causes for hyperglycemia include
   pancreatitis and stress response in the setting of sepsis and acute
   illness.  Discontinued insulin gtt and started insulin ss on [**10-2**] (fixed
   glargine 38u qhs+ISS)
   - continue glargine 38u qhs
   - continue ISS
   .
   # Anemia
 Stable around hct of 26.  The most likely cause is anemia of
   inflammation in the setting of acute disease. There was initial concern
   for hemolysis but haptoglobin elevated and peripheral smear essentially
   normal. Hemorrhagic pancreatitis not seen on CT abd. Heme positive
   stools on admission
 may be due to gastritis, PUD. Other possible
   sources include diverticular bleed given known diverticulosis or colon
   cancer given h/o adenomas. No history of varices.  Also possibly
   related to stomach erosions seen on ERCP from OG trauma.
   - continue to monitor Hct
   - continue EPO
   - continue IV PPI
   .
   # GI bleed: history of guiac positive stools.  Hct has been stable.
   - c.diff neg x2 since the most recent GIB  so PO Vanco was d/c
   ..
   # hyponatremia and hyperphosphatemia: in the setting of ARF and volume
   overload, phos has currently normalized and sodium was 134 today
   - on CVVH. followed by renal
   .
   # Afib with RVR
 has resolved and he remains in sinus with good rate
   control.  Prior episode was most likely secondary to the fever, pain
   and inflammatory state.
   - no anticoagulation for now given only one episode in the setting of
   acute illness
   .
   # Agitation/anxiety: patient tolerated PMV well, and has been able to
   communicate with family
   - consider ativan if anxiety worsens
   .
   # Goals of care:
   - update family daily

The patient is an 83-year-old male with a history of pancreatitis, respiratory failure, renal failure, and sepsis. He is currently on mechanical ventilation due to respiratory failure and has been experiencing episodes of hypotension and clotting issues with the CVVH machine. The patient has been titrated down on Neo for blood pressure support and is tolerating it well. RSBI is in the 50s, and the plan is to attempt a trial of pressure support. The patient is receiving multiple antibiotics for various infections, including cefepime for a Klebsiella infection in the sputum, micafungin for yeast in the catheter tip culture, and vancomycin for possible catheter-related bacteremia. 

The patient's abdominal CT shows severe pancreatitis, moderate ascites, bilateral pleural effusions with compressive atelectasis, and a simple cyst in the right kidney. The patient's blood cultures have been negative, but there is evidence of infection in the urine and stool. 

The patient's respiratory status is complicated by volume overload, likely secondary to acute renal failure and abdominal distention impeding lung expansion. The patient has been weaned off the ventilator briefly but required reintubation due to dyspnea. 

The patient's renal function is poor, with very poor urine output and difficulty tolerating CVVH due to hypotension.

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is currently in the ICU with multiple ongoing medical issues. 

The patient is experiencing severe pancreatitis, as indicated by the CT abdomen results. There is also moderate ascites, bilateral moderate-sized pleural effusion with compressive atelectasis, and a simple cyst in the right kidney. These findings suggest potential complications related to the pancreatitis, such as pleural effusion and atelectasis due to inflammation and fluid accumulation.

The patient is also on continuous renal replacement therapy (CVVH) for renal support, which has been stopped temporarily due to clotting issues with the machine. This indicates that the patient may have acute kidney injury or severe renal dysfunction requiring dialysis.

The patient's respiratory status is being closely monitored with the assistance of a ventilator. The RSBI (rapid shallow breathing index) is in the 50s, indicating the possibility of weaning from mechanical ventilation. However, the presence of bilateral pleural effusions may pose a challenge in this process.

In terms of infections, the patient is receiving multiple antibiotics including cefepime, vancomycin, and micafungin. There is also a concern for Clostridium difficile infection (C. diff) given the recent stool toxin test. Imaging of the abdomen is recommended to evaluate for any pancreatic fluid collection or abscess.

Overall, the potential medical complications that can arise from this patient's current condition include worsening respiratory distress due to pleural effusions,

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is an 83-year-old male with a history of pancreatitis, respiratory failure, renal failure, and sepsis. He currently has metabolic acidosis, volume overload, and is on mechanical ventilation. His sputum culture grew Klebsiella, and he is being treated with cefepime. The patient's blood culture showed yeast, and he is being treated with micafungin. He has a history of diarrhea and is experiencing agitation and anxiety. The patient's recent lab results show an elevated white blood cell count, low hemoglobin, and elevated creatinine levels. His imaging results indicate severe pancreatitis with no evidence of pancreatic necrosis or pseudocysts. The patient's goals of care include daily updates for the family and continuing with the current treatment plan.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory status is concerning due to the rapid re-accumulation of pleural effusion and difficulty weaning off the ventilator. There is a need to address underlying COPD and manage volume overload.

2. Sepsis: The patient has shown improvement after changing lines and catheters, but ongoing monitoring and treatment are required. Antibiotics should be continued, and fungal infection should be addressed.

3. Acute on Chronic Renal Failure: The patient's renal function is deteriorating, with poor urine output and increasing creatinine levels. Hemodialysis may be necessary, and careful electrolyte management is needed.

Summary:
The patient is an 83-year-old male with a history of pancreatitis, respiratory failure, renal failure, and sepsis. He currently has metabolic acidosis and is experiencing volume overload, which is contributing to his poor respiratory status. The patient's pleural effusion rapidly re-accumulated after thoracentesis, and he has been unable to tolerate continuous venovenous hemofiltration (CVVH) due to low blood pressure.

The patient's sputum culture grew Klebsiella, and he is being treated with cefepime as per Infectious Disease recommendations. The patient also has a catheter-related yeast infection, presumptively not Candida albicans, and is being treated with micafungin. The patient's underlying COPD should be managed with MDIs including albuterol.

The patient's acute kidney injury (AKI) is likely due to a combination of factors including acute tubular necrosis (ATN), pre-renal azotemia, and allergic interstitial nephritis (AIN). The patient has poor urine output, and efforts are being made to optimize renal function. The patient may require dialysis to manage his renal failure.

The patient has gallstone pancreatitis with severe inflammation but no evidence of pancreatic necrosis or pseudocysts. His post-pyloric feeding tube is in place, and he is tolerating tube feeds with erythromycin.

The patient has a history of type II diabetes mellitus,

The patient has been diagnosed with gallstone pancreatitis and has been on post-pyloric feeding tube since September 27th. His blood cultures have shown growth of yeast and Gram-negative rods, including Klebsiella pneumoniae, for which he is receiving appropriate antibiotics. The patient has been on CVVH but has had difficulty tolerating it due to hypotension, ectopy, and clotting in the machine. His renal function is worsening, and he has very poor urine output. 

The patient's laboratory results show leukocytosis with a white blood cell count of 28.5, anemia with a hemoglobin level of 6.1 g/dL, elevated blood urea nitrogen (BUN) and creatinine levels, hyperglycemia, and hyponatremia. The patient's vital signs are stable, with a heart rate of 83 beats per minute, blood pressure of 119/49 mmHg, respiratory rate of 22 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 100

   Mr. [**Known lastname 9611**] is an 83M with pancreatitis, with respiratory failure, renal
   failure and now with sepsis.
   .
   # Respiratory failure
 currently s/p tracheostomy ([**9-28**]) and right
   sided thoracentesis ([**10-9**]). Pleural effusion rapidly re-accumulated in
   right lung after throacentesis, the effect was not durable.  The
   respiratory failure is likely secondary to volume overload in the
   setting of acute renal failure and abdominal distention impeding lung
   expansion.  Sputum cx grew klebsiella. Also has metabolic acidosis
   making it difficult to go off ventilator. Was briefly weaned off
   ventilator yesterday, but back on bc dyspneic.
   - currently on AC, tolerated PS yesterday, and periods of time with PMV
   as well, patient has been getting subjectively short of breath with PMV
   in place, however he was able to maintain his oxygen saturation without
   any increase in RR
   - sputum cultures => klebsiella, on cefepime per ID
   - sputum gram stain from [**10-20**] also shows GNR
   - treat pt
s underlying COPD with MDIs, incl albuterol
   - patient currently volume overloaded with almost no urine output, only
   93cc in past 24 hours, and he has been unable to tolerate CVVH to this
   point, volume overload likely contributing to poor respiratory status
   .
   # Sepsis: had lines and catheters changed and antibiotics continued in
   effort to treat possible catheter related gram positive bacteremia.
   Cath tip growing yeast, presumptively not c. albicans.  Pt has slight
   improvement in leukocytosis, afebrile overnight.  Other sources include
   urine, which grew yeasts, sputum which grew pansensitive klebsiella,
   and stool as pt had history of diarrhea.
   - now on vasopressin for BP support, will continue to down titrate and
   BP
s will allow, BP
s better off HD
   - as per ID rec, started micafungin for yeast in catheter tip cx, will
   complete a [**8-3**] day course.
   - pan-sensitive Klebsiella in sputum from [**10-13**], continue cefepime for
   additional GNR coverage.
   - dose vanc by level, level this morning was 17.3, will need additional
   doses of vancomycin and cefepime post HD
   - ID still requesting [**Last Name (LF) **], [**First Name3 (LF) **] discuss how it will change our
   management since that will likely mean removal of post-pyloric feeding
   tube, additionally patient has remained afebrile, and blood cx
s have
   cleared since initial positive cultures so endocarditis seems to be a
   less likely diagnosis at this time
   - follow lactate
   - maintain goal MAP>65, CVP>10, ScvO2>70% with pressors if needed
   .
   # Acute on chronic renal failure Renal following. Creat worsening.
   Diff includes ATN, pre-renal and AIN. Urine eos neg x2.  He has very
   poor to almost no urine output.
   - patient tried on HD today with pressors to help support his BP, renal
   optimistic that they will find a way for him to tolerate HD
   - renal concerned that he should have a line holiday, since maybe we
   have just been unable to get the fungal cultures at the right time,
   will hold off for now since re-siting all of his lines will be
   problem[**Name (NI) 595**] since that has already been done during his course
   - electrolyte management with HD
   .
   # Gallstone Pancreatitis
 repeat CT abd without IV contrast unchanged,
   still has massive inflammation in the abdomen, no evidence of
   pancreatic necrosis or presence of pseudocysts. Has had post-pyloric
   feeding tube in place since [**9-27**].
   - patient currently tolerating tube feeds with erythromycin
   - OGT still in place
   - CT abd/pelvis with severe unchanged pancreatitis
   - continue erythromycin
   - continue to trend LFTs, lipase as normalized
   - check ionized calcium daily
 replete as necessary
   .
   # DM
 pt has type II DM, currently with good BS control
   - continue glargine 38u qhs
   - continue ISS
   .
   # Anemia
 bleeding from A line overnight, with drop in HCT to 19.3,
   patient transfused 1unit PRBC
   - continue to monitor Hct
   - continue EPO
   .
   # GI bleed: history of guiac positive stools.  Hct has been stable.
   - cont IV PPI
   ..
   # hyponatremia and hyperphosphatemia: in the setting of ARF and volume
   overload, have resolved
   - electrolyte management with HD
   .
   # Afib with RVR
 has resolved and he remains in sinus with good rate
   control.  Prior episode was most likely secondary to the fever, pain
   and inflammatory state.
   .
   # Agitation/anxiety: patient tolerated PMV well, and has been able to

   - consider ativan if anxiety worsens

Summary:
The patient is an 83-year-old male with pancreatitis, respiratory failure, renal failure, and sepsis. He has a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), type II diabetes mellitus (DM), anemia, gastrointestinal (GI) bleed, hyponatremia, hyperphosphatemia, and atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response (Afib/RVR). The patient is currently intubated and on mechanical ventilation with pressure-controlled ventilation mode (PCV/SBT). He is receiving multiple medications including vasopressin, micafungin, cefepime, vancomycin, and erythromycin. The patient's vital signs include a temperature of 37.1°C, heart rate of 87 bpm, blood pressure of 146/56 mmHg, respiratory rate of 24 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 95%. Laboratory results show leukocytosis with a white blood cell count of 28.5 K/uL, elevated creatinine levels, and positive cultures for klebsiella, yeast, and GNR. Imaging studies reveal severe pancreatitis with no evidence of pancreatic necrosis or pseudocysts.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is complicated by volume overload, acute renal failure, abdominal distention, and underlying COPD. There is a concern for recurrent pleural effusion and difficulty weaning off the

Summary:
The patient is an 83-year-old male with pancreatitis, respiratory failure, renal failure, and sepsis. The patient's respiratory failure is likely secondary to volume overload, pneumonia with sputum culture growing Klebsiella, and underlying COPD. The patient is currently on mechanical ventilation and has undergone tracheostomy.

The patient's renal failure is likely due to acute tubular necrosis (ATN), and the patient has poor urine output. The patient is planned for dialysis on Thursday or Friday, and there is a discussion about changing to continuous renal replacement therapy (CRRT) to mobilize more fluid.

The patient has severe gallstone pancreatitis without evidence of pancreatic necrosis or pseudocysts. The patient is tolerating post-pyloric tube feeds and erythromycin is being used.

The patient has type II diabetes mellitus with good blood sugar control and is on glargine insulin subcutaneously at night.

The patient has anemia, which may be due to bleeding from an arterial line. The patient has been transfused one unit of packed red blood cells.

The patient has a history of gastrointestinal bleeding with positive guaiac test in stools. Prophylactic IV PPI is being continued.

The patient had atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response, which has resolved, and the patient remains in sinus rhythm with good rate control.

The patient has agitation and anxiety, which have been managed with non-pharmacological interventions. Consider

Summary:
Summary of the progress note:
The patient is a 69-year-old male with a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), diabetes mellitus type II, and hypertension. He is currently in the ICU due to severe sepsis with organ dysfunction, acute renal failure, hypotension, anemia, and other complications.

24-hour events:
The patient tolerated two periods of 30 minutes off the ventilator yesterday and is being weaned off phenylephrine through the night and this morning. His blood pressure is improving, and he is stable. His electrolytes are acceptable, and his acid-base status is okay. He remains significantly volume overloaded, which is an impediment to weaning off the ventilator and ambulation. His blood cultures remain negative.

Assessment and plan:
The patient has several ongoing problems, including sepsis with severe organ dysfunction, ineffective coping, diarrhea, alteration in nutrition, anemia, impaired aerobic capacity/endurance, impaired airway clearance, impaired balance, impaired gait, impaired knowledge, impaired motor function, impaired ventilation, atrial fibrillation (AFIB), impaired skin integrity, fever of unknown origin (FUO), acute renal failure, acute pancreatitis, respiratory failure (not ARDS), pain control, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) exacerbation, diabetes mellitus type II, and hypertension.

The patient continues on antibiotics, and his white blood cell count remains elevated. His hematocrit is stable,

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
- Patient is an 83-year-old male with pancreatitis, respiratory failure, renal failure, and sepsis.
- He has a history of COPD, gallstone pancreatitis, diabetes mellitus type II, anemia, GI bleed, hyponatremia, hyperphosphatemia, and atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response.
- The patient has been intubated and placed on mechanical ventilation.
- He is currently on vasopressin for blood pressure support and has had multiple lines and catheters changed.
- Sputum cultures have grown klebsiella, and there is a yeast infection in the urine.
- The patient is volume overloaded with minimal urine output.
- Renal function is deteriorating, and he is experiencing acute kidney injury.
- Pancreatitis is still present without evidence of necrosis or pseudocysts.
- The patient is tolerating tube feeds.
- His diabetes is well-controlled with glargine and ISS.
- Anemia has been managed with a blood transfusion and EPO.
- There is a history of GI bleed, but HCT has been stable.
- Hyponatremia and hyperphosphatemia have resolved.
- The patient's atrial fibrillation with RVR has resolved, and he is now in sinus rhythm.
- The patient is agitated and anxious but tolerates PMV well.
- Goals of care include daily updates to the family.

Potential Medical Comp

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is an 83-year-old male with a history of pancreatitis, respiratory failure, renal failure, and sepsis. He has been admitted to the ICU and is currently on mechanical ventilation. The patient has multiple medical complications including pneumonia, catheter-related bacteremia, urinary tract infection, and gastrointestinal bleeding. He is also experiencing acute on chronic renal failure, hyponatremia, hyperphosphatemia, anemia, and diabetes mellitus.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory failure is likely secondary to volume overload, acute renal failure, abdominal distention impeding lung expansion, and pneumonia with sputum culture growing Klebsiella.
2. Sepsis: The patient has sepsis with multiple sources of infection including catheter-related bacteremia, urinary tract infection, and pneumonia.
3. Acute on Chronic Renal Failure: The patient has acute on chronic renal failure with worsening creatinine levels, likely due to acute tubular necrosis (ATN). He has very poor to almost no urine output.
4. Gastrointestinal Bleeding: The patient has a history of gastrointestinal bleeding with guaiac positive stools. There is ongoing monitoring and management of this condition.
5. Anemia: The patient has anemia due to bleeding from an arterial line and a history of gastrointestinal bleeding. He has been transfused with 1 unit of packed red blood cells.
6. Hyponatremia

   Assessment and Plan
   Mr. [**Known lastname 9611**] is an 83M with pancreatitis, with respiratory failure, renal
   failure and now with sepsis.
   .
   # Respiratory failure
 s/p tracheostomy ([**9-28**]) and s/p right sided
   thoracentesis ([**10-9**]). Pleural effusion rapidly re-accumulated in right
   lung after throacentesis, the effect was not durable.  The respiratory
   failure is likely secondary to volume overload in the setting of acute
   renal failure and abdominal distention impeding lung expansion,
   additionally the pneumonia with sputum cx that grew klebsiella.
   - pt. tolerated two SBT
s for 30 minutes yesterday, but did not
   tolerate SBT this AM w ABG showing pH 7.
 will try SBT again this
   afternoon
   - sputum cultures => klebsiella, on cefepime per ID
   - sputum gram stain from [**10-20**] also shows GNR
   - treat pt
s underlying COPD with MDIs, incl albuterol
   - patient currently volume overloaded with almost little urine output
   - given lasix 80mg IV and didn
t put out much urine, so may give a dose
   of 160mg IV lasix later this afternoon
   .
   # Sepsis: had lines and catheters changed and antibiotics continued in
   effort to treat possible catheter related gram positive bacteremia.
   Cath tip growing [**Month/Year (2) 1564**], presumptively not c. albicans.  Pt has slight
   improvement in leukocytosis, afebrile overnight.  Other sources include
   urine, which grew yeasts, sputum which grew pansensitive klebsiella,
   and stool as pt had history of diarrhea.
   - now transitioning to vasopressin for BP support, will continue to
   wean down phenylephrine
   - as per ID rec, getting micafungin for [**Month/Year (2) 1564**] in catheter tip cx, will
   complete a [**8-3**] day course
has had 7 days
   - pan-sensitive Klebsiella in sputum from [**10-13**], continue cefepime for
   additional GNR coverage.
   - dose vanc by level, level this morning was 18.2, will dose another
   500mg this morning, will need additional doses of vancomycin and
   cefepime post HD
   - follow lactate, had trended down post HD
   - maintain goal MAP>65, CVP>10, ScvO2>70% with pressors if needed
   .
   # Acute on chronic renal failure Renal following. Creat relatively
   stable, not improving, likely due to ATN. Urine eos neg x2.  He has
   very poor to almost no urine output.
   - patient tolerated HD with pressors, next HD session per renal
   scheduled for Friday, which may be tolerated better when on vasopressin
   .
   # Gallstone Pancreatitis
 repeat CT abd without IV contrast unchanged,
   still has massive inflammation in the abdomen, no evidence of
   pancreatic necrosis or presence of pseudocysts. Has had post-pyloric
   feeding tube in place since [**9-27**].  CT abd/pelvis with severe unchanged
   pancreatitis
   - patient currently tolerating tube feeds with erythromycin
   - will get PEG tube tomorrow by IP
   - continue erythromycin
   - continue to trend LFTs, lipase as normalized
   - check ionized calcium daily
 replete as necessary
   .
   # DM
 pt has type II DM, currently with good BS control
   - continue glargine 38u qhs
   - continue ISS
   .
   # Anemia
  Hct stable.
   - continue to monitor Hct
   - continue EPO
   .
   # GI bleed: history of guiac positive stools.  Hct has been stable.
   - cont IV PPI
   .
   # Agitation/anxiety: patient tolerated PMV well, and has been able to
   communicate with family.  Was started on citalopram 10mg this week for
   depression, but consider that he probably has more grief than
   depression.
   - consider ativan if anxiety worsens
   .
   # Goals of care:
   - update family daily

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is an 83-year-old male with a history of pancreatitis, respiratory failure, renal failure, and now sepsis. He has been admitted to the ICU and is currently on mechanical ventilation. The patient's respiratory failure is likely due to volume overload, acute renal failure, and abdominal distention impeding lung expansion. He also has pneumonia with sputum culture showing Klebsiella. The patient has been treated with cefepime, lasix, and vasopressin for sepsis. His renal failure is likely secondary to acute tubular necrosis (ATN). The patient has gallstone pancreatitis with severe inflammation in the abdomen, but no evidence of pancreatic necrosis or presence of pseudocysts. He has a history of type II diabetes mellitus and is currently well-controlled on glargine. The patient also has anemia, gastrointestinal bleeding, and agitation/anxiety. The goals of care include daily updates for the family and continued ICU care.

Potential medical complications that can arise include worsening respiratory failure, progression of renal failure, sepsis, gastrointestinal bleeding, and complications related to the patient's diabetes and anemia.

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is an 83-year-old male with a history of pancreatitis, respiratory failure, renal failure, and sepsis. He has undergone several interventions including tracheostomy, right-sided thoracentesis, placement of a post-pyloric feeding tube, and percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy (PEG) tube insertion. The patient's current condition includes volume overload, pneumonia with sputum culture growing klebsiella, and positive yeast growth in catheter tip culture. He is also experiencing acute on chronic renal failure with poor urine output and has a history of gallstone pancreatitis without evidence of pancreatic necrosis or pseudocysts. Other medical conditions include diabetes mellitus type II, anemia, and a history of gastrointestinal bleeding. The patient's vital signs are stable, and he is receiving appropriate antibiotics, antifungals, and supportive care.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Sepsis: The patient's sepsis may worsen if there is no improvement in response to antibiotic therapy or if new sources of infection are identified.
2. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory failure may persist if there is continued volume overload, pneumonia, or inability to tolerate weaning from mechanical ventilation.
3. Acute on Chronic Renal Failure: The patient's renal failure may not improve if there is no response to dialysis or if the underlying cause of acute renal injury is not addressed.
4. Pneumonia: The patient

The patient's respiratory failure is likely secondary to Klebsiella pneumonia and volume overload in the setting of acute renal failure and abdominal distention impeding lung expansion. 

The patient has sepsis caused by coagulation-negative Staphylococcus bacteremia. Previous lines and catheters have been changed, and antibiotics have been continued in an effort to treat possible catheter-related Gram-positive bacteremia. The catheter tip is growing yeast, presumptively not Candida albicans. The urine has also grown yeast, and the sputum grew pan-sensitive Klebsiella. 

The patient continues to be on pressors for blood pressure support and is being weaned down from phenylephrine. Micafungin and vancomycin will be discontinued as per ID recommendations. 

The patient has acute kidney injury (ATN) due to pancreatitis, but renal function is improving due to good urine output from the lasix drip. Hemodialysis may not be necessary if the lasix drip continues to provide good urine output. 

The patient's gallstone pancreatitis is clinically improving, and he can start receiving feeds through the new PEG tube.

2. Acute renal failure: The patient has a rising creatinine level and a baseline BUN/creatinine of 26-27/1.4-1.5. This indicates a decline in kidney function, which can progress to acute renal failure if not managed appropriately.

3. Pancreatitis: The patient has evidence of acute pancreatitis, as indicated by elevated lipase levels and inflammation seen on a CT scan. Pancreatitis can lead to complications such as necrosis or abscess formation if not treated promptly.

4. Anemia: The patient's low hemoglobin level suggests anemia, which may be due to chronic disease, blood loss, or other underlying causes. Anemia can contribute to poor oxygen delivery to tissues and may require treatment with blood transfusions or erythropoietin.

5. Sepsis: The patient is diagnosed with severe sepsis with organ dysfunction. Sepsis is a life-threatening condition that arises when the body's response to infection causes widespread inflammation. It can lead to organ failure if not promptly recognized and treated.

Summary:
The patient is an 83-year-old male with a history of pancreatitis, respiratory failure, renal failure, and now sepsis. He is currently on mechanical ventilation, vasopressors, and has had several lines and catheters placed. The patient's condition is complicated by several factors, including a new infection with pseudomonas aeruginosa, which may be contributing to his respiratory failure. He also has a coagulase-negative staphylococcal bacteremia, likely related to a catheter. The patient's renal function is improving, but he still requires dialysis. He also has a history of gallstone pancreatitis, diabetes mellitus, anemia, and agitation/anxiety.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure is likely secondary to klebsiella pneumonia and volume overload. He is currently on pressure support and tolerating well. However, the new pseudomonas infection may further worsen his respiratory status.
2. Sepsis: The patient has sepsis caused by coagulase-negative staphylococcal bacteremia. Despite changing lines and antibiotics, the infection persists, and there is a risk of continued systemic inflammation and organ dysfunction.
3. Acute kidney injury: The patient has acute renal failure, which is presumed to be due to acute tubular necrosis (ATN). His renal function is slowly improving, but he still requires dialysis.

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is an 83-year-old male with pancreatitis, respiratory failure, renal failure, and sepsis. He has been admitted to the ICU and is currently on a lasix drip, pressure support, and vasopressin. The patient's recent sputum culture showed pansensitive klebsiella, so the antibiotic regimen will be changed to zosyn based on sensitivities. The patient's underlying COPD will be treated with MDIs including albuterol. The patient's sepsis is due to coag-negative staph bacteremia, and the catheter tip grew yeast. The patient's urine and sputum also grew yeast. The patient's acute renal failure is presumed to be due to acute tubular necrosis (ATN), and his ability to produce urine has improved with the lasix drip. The patient's gallstone pancreatitis appears to be improving, and he is being fed through a PEG tube. The patient has type II diabetes and had low blood sugars while NPO, so he will restart tube feeds today. The patient has a history of GI bleed and is being monitored for anemia. The patient is also experiencing agitation/anxiety and is being started on citalopram for depression. The goals of care include updating the family daily, providing ICU care, and managing nutrition, glycemic control, and prophylaxis. The patient's disposition is ICU.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure:

The patient has had several lines and catheters changed, and antibiotics have been continued to treat possible catheter-related gram-positive bacteremia. The patient's renal failure is presumed to be due to acute tubular necrosis (ATN) and is being managed with a lasix drip. The patient's gallstone pancreatitis appears to be improving, and he will be fed through a new percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy (PEG) tube. he has

    Mr. [**Known lastname 9611**] is an 83M with pancreatitis, with respiratory failure, renal
   failure and now with sepsis.
   .
   # Respiratory failure
 s/p tracheostomy ([**9-28**]) and s/p right sided
   thoracentesis ([**10-9**]) Respiratory failure likely secondary to klebsiella
   pneumonia and volume overload in the setting of acute renal failure and
   abdominal distention impeding lung expansion.   Currently on pressure
   support, tolerating well.   Pt currently on lasix drip, tolerating
   well.
   - new pseudomonas in his sputum, may be contributing to his respiratory
   failure
   - Continue cefepime and add inhaled tobra as per ID recs
   - treat pt
s underlying COPD with MDIs, incl albuterol
   - continue lasix drip w goal net Ins/Outs even for today, prefer not to
   diurese more than 1.5L per day
   .
   # Sepsis:  Coag Neg Staph Bacteremia.  Previously had lines and
   catheters changed and antibiotics continued in effort to treat possible
   catheter related gram positive bacteremia.  Cath tip growing yeast,
   presumptively not c. albicans.   Urine has also grown yeast, sputum
   grew pansensitive klebsiella.  Patient continues on pressors.
   - sputum culture from [**2153-10-20**] is growing resistant pseudomonas with
   small amount of klebsiella, sputum cx from [**10-25**] with Gram negative
   rods, will f/u final cultures and speciation, will add inhaled
   tobramycin based on sensitivities and ID recs
   - patient only on vasopressin for BP support, will wean as tolerated,
   will likely need to back down on diuresis as his CVP=7 currently and is
   still on pressors, so he is third spacing a large amount of fluid but
   intra-vascularly likely volume down
   - as per ID recs, will DC micafungin (day 10) and vancomycin (day
   14)after  today
   - for pan-sensitive Klebsiella in sputum, will change to zosyn based on
   pseudomonas sensitivites
   .
   # Acute on chronic --  Pt continues to respond very well to the lasix
   drip, making good urine, with urine output  with an average of
   100cc/hr. Renal failure presumed to be due to ATN.  Creatinine
   increasing, but cannot consider previous Cr values accurate while on
   CVVH and HD, so actual glomerular function is not likely
   worsening
likely improving due to improved ability to produce urine.
   Goal to avoid further HD.
   - continue lasix drip, titrated to goal I/Os of even today (no more
   than 2L because he may not be able to mobilize extra third-spaced body
   fluids that quickly into intravascular space)
   - may need to decrease lasix gtt today because CVP has been low, and pt
   should have enough fluids to be on pressors
   - renal continuing to follow
   .
   # Gallstone Pancreatitis
 clinically appears to be improving
   - feeds through PEG tube
   - continue erythromycin for gastric motility
   - no need to trend LFTs regularly
   - replete calcium as necessary
   .
   # DM
 pt has type II DM, sugars slightly elevated over last day or so
   after tube feeds have started, but not out of control
   - continue glargine 38u qhs
   - continue ISS
   .
   # Anemia
   Hx of GI bleed.  transfused 1unit pRBCs yesterday to Hct
   24.
   - continue to monitor Hct
   - continue EPO
   - continue IV PPI
   .
   # Agitation/anxiety: patient tolerated PMV well, and has been able to
   communicate with family.  Was started on citalopram 10mg this week for
   depression, but consider that he probably has more grief than
   depression.
   - consider ativan if anxiety worsens
   - continue citalopram 10mg and consider increase to 20mg in [**1-26**] weeks
   .
   # Goals of care:

   -          patient OOB Daily

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is an 83-year-old male with a history of pancreatitis, respiratory failure, renal failure, and sepsis. He has been admitted to the ICU and is currently on mechanical ventilation. His vital signs include a temperature of 36.7°C (98°F), heart rate of 72 bpm, blood pressure of 122/42 mmHg, respiratory rate of 12 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 98%. The patient's recent laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count, slightly low hemoglobin levels, and elevated creatinine levels. The patient has multiple comorbidities including COPD, diabetes mellitus, anemia, and gallstone pancreatitis. He is currently receiving multiple medications including vasopressin, furosemide, pantoprazole, heparin sodium, and cefepime.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory failure is likely secondary to klebsiella pneumonia and volume overload. He is currently on pressure support and tolerating well. However, new pseudomonas in his sputum may contribute to his respiratory failure.
2. Sepsis: The patient has sepsis caused by coagulase-negative staphylococcus bacteremia. He has had lines and catheters changed, and antibiotics have been continued to treat possible catheter-related gram-positive bacteremia. Yeast has also grown from the urine and sputum cultures

Summary:
The patient is an 83-year-old male with pancreatitis, respiratory failure, renal failure, and sepsis. He has been treated for Klebsiella pneumonia and is currently on pressure support ventilation due to volume overload and acute renal failure. The patient also has COPD and is being treated with MDIs including albuterol. 

The patient's sepsis is caused by coag-negative Staph bacteremia and yeast growing from the catheter tip. He has completed a full course of vancomycin and micafungin. The sputum has also grown yeast, and the urine has grown yeast as well. 

The patient's acute renal failure is presumed to be due to acute tubular necrosis (ATN). His creatinine levels are increasing, but previous values may not be accurate due to hemodialysis treatments. 

The patient's gallstone pancreatitis appears to be improving, and he is tolerating tube feeds well. His type II diabetes is slightly elevated, but not out of control. 

The patient has a history of GI bleed and received a blood transfusion yesterday. He is being monitored for anemia and will continue with erythropoietin and IV proton pump inhibitor. 

The patient is also experiencing agitation and anxiety, and citalopram has been started for depression. Consideration is being given to using ativan if anxiety worsens. 

The goals of care include updating the family daily, keeping the patient out of bed daily

The patient's current condition shows improvement in secretions and tolerance of pressure support ventilation (PSV). Antibiotic treatment has been completed for coag-negative staph bacteremia, and antifungal treatment has been completed for positive catheter tip findings. Vasopressin weaning is planned today. The patient also has acute renal failure, pancreatitis, and chronic anemia.

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is an 83-year-old male with a history of pancreatitis, respiratory failure, sepsis, and improving renal failure. He is currently being treated for klebsiella pneumonia and has a new pseudomonas infection in his sputum. The patient is also experiencing gallstone pancreatitis, right-sided swelling, diabetes mellitus, anemia, and agitation/anxiety. His goals of care include daily updates for the family, keeping the patient out of bed, and ICU care.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory failure: The patient has been diagnosed with respiratory failure secondary to klebsiella pneumonia. He is currently on pressure support ventilation and is being treated with antibiotics. However, there is a possibility of worsening respiratory failure due to the new pseudomonas infection in his sputum.

2. Sepsis: The patient has a history of sepsis caused by coagulation-negative Staphylococcus bacteremia and yeast growing from the catheter tip. Although the patient has been treated with vancomycin and micafungin, there is still a risk of sepsis recurrence due to the presence of yeast in the urine and sputum.

3. Acute kidney injury (AKI): The patient has acute renal failure, which is presumed to be due to acute tubular necrosis (ATN). His creatinine levels are increasing, but it is difficult to determine the actual glomerular function as previous Cr

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is an 83-year-old male with a history of pancreatitis, respiratory failure, sepsis, and improving renal failure. He has been treated for klebsiella pneumonia and is currently on a lasix drip to manage volume overload. The patient also has pseudomonas in his sputum, which may be contributing to his respiratory failure. He is being treated with cefepime and inhaled tobramycin, and his underlying COPD is being managed with MDIs including albuterol.

The patient's sepsis is being treated with a full course of vancomycin and micafungin, which were discontinued on [**10-28**]. He has also grown yeast in his urine and sputum. The patient continues on pressors and is being closely monitored.

The patient's acute renal failure is presumed to be due to acute tubular necrosis (ATN). His creatinine levels are increasing, but previous values may not be accurate while on CVVH and HD. The goal is to avoid further hemodialysis (HD) and to wean the lasix drip while monitoring urine output and daily creatinine levels.

The patient's gallstone pancreatitis appears to be improving clinically, although radiographically it appears the same. He is being fed through a [**Month/Day (1) **] tube without problems, and erythromycin is being continued for gastric motility.

The patient's right-sided

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is an 83-year-old male with a history of pancreatitis, respiratory failure, sepsis, and improving renal failure. He has been admitted to the ICU and is currently on mechanical ventilation due to respiratory failure caused by klebsiella pneumonia. He also has a history of gallstone pancreatitis, type II diabetes mellitus, anemia, and agitation/anxiety. The patient's current vital signs include a temperature of 36.2 C, heart rate of 72 bpm, blood pressure of 131/48 mmHg, respiratory rate of 12 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 100% on room air. His physical examination reveals distant heart sounds, clear lung fields, abdominal distention, and edema in both upper and lower extremities.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory failure is likely secondary to klebsiella pneumonia. There is a new pseudomonas infection in his sputum, which may contribute to his respiratory failure. It is important to continue the current antibiotics (cefepime and inhaled tobramycin) and treat his underlying COPD with MDIs including albuterol.

2. Sepsis: The patient had coagulation-negative Staph bacteremia and yeast growing from the catheter tip. He should have been treated with full courses of vancomycin and micafungin, both of which were discontinued on 10/28.

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is an 83-year-old male with pancreatitis, respiratory failure, improving renal failure, and sepsis. He has been treated for klebsiella pneumonia and is currently on a lasix drip, tolerating well. The patient also has underlying COPD and a history of gastrointestinal bleeding. He has been started on citalopram for depression but may have more grief than depression. The patient's goals of care include updating the family daily and keeping the patient out of bed daily.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory failure due to klebsiella pneumonia and volume overload.
2. Sepsis caused by coag-neg staph bacteremia and yeast infection.
3. Acute renal failure due to acute tubular necrosis (ATN).
4. Gallstone pancreatitis that appears to be improving.
5. Type II diabetes with slightly elevated blood sugars.
6. Anemia due to gastrointestinal bleeding.
7. Agitation and anxiety, possibly related to grief or depression.

Please note that this summary and potential medical complications are based on the provided progress note. Additional information and evaluation may be necessary for a complete assessment.

   than in the past 48 hours - goal 1L negative fluid balance for the day.
   Creat has been stable; BUN up slightly in the past week with diuresis.
   On rounds, patient placed on PSV 5/5 and FIO2 reduced to 0.5. Patient
   appears comfortable with RR < 20 and O2 sat at 100%. I would not be
   overly concerned about PaCO2 in the high 50's with pH above 7.30. His
   kidneys may be able to make adequate bicarb to compensate (last bicarb
   29). Higher PaCO2 will ultimately make it easier for him to breathe off
   the ventilator.
   Completing course of antibiotics.
   Try to place PICC and remove central venous access and dialysis
   catheter.

Summary:
The patient is a 69-year-old male with a chief complaint of respiratory failure, renal failure, and pancreatitis. He has been admitted to the ICU and is currently on various medications including lasix, vasopressin, heparin sodium, and others. His vital signs are stable with a blood pressure of 105/50 mmHg, heart rate of 88 bpm, respiratory rate of 12 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 100%. He has a tracheostomy tube in place and is on CPAP/PSV mode with a tidal volume of 731 mL, positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) of 5 cmH2O, and fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) set at 50%. The patient's ABG results show a pH of 7.37, PaCO2 of 49 mmHg, and PaO2/FiO2 ratio of 180. Physical examination reveals no acute distress, well-nourished appearance, and no signs of jaundice or clubbing. Lab results indicate elevated WBC count, low hemoglobin, elevated creatinine, and other abnormalities. The patient's renal function is compromised with a baseline BUN/creatinine of 26-27/1.4-1.5. He also has acute pancreatitis with elevated lipase levels and CT scan findings consistent with inflammation. The patient's pain is controlled with IV morphine

   Mr. [**Known lastname 9611**] is an 83M with pancreatitis, with respiratory failure, sepsis,
   and improving renal failure.
   .
   # Chest pain
   New this AM, describes tightening.  Cardiac enzymes negative.  EKG
   shows LBBB, which he has had in the past, though last EKG on [**10-25**] does
   not show LBBB.  Cannot evaluate ST-T wave elevations in setting of
   LBBB.  Likely has unstable angina.
   - give Nitro sublingual as needed and monitor blood pressure
   - may need to restart pressors to support blood pressure if Nitro drops
   BP
   - cycle Cardiac enzymes
   - Call cardiology if cardiac enzymes positive
   .
   # Respiratory failure
 s/p tracheostomy ([**9-28**]) and s/p right sided
   thoracentesis ([**10-9**]) Respiratory failure likely secondary to klebsiella
   pneumonia, still being treated and volume overload in the setting of
   acute renal failure.   On pressure support overnight and this AM on
   [**8-29**]. pseudomonas in his sputum, may be contributing to his respiratory
   failure
   - Continue cefepime and inhaled tobra as per ID recs (day #10 of 21 day
   course)
   - treat pt
s underlying COPD with MDIs, incl albuterol
   - continue lasix drip w goal net Ins/Outs -500mL for today, no more
   than 1L per day
   - Holding on Spontaneous breathing trial for now because of chest pain
   evaluation
   .
   # Sepsis:  Coag Neg Staph Bacteremia and yeast growing from catheter
   tip should be treated by now with full course of vancomycin and
   micafungin, both DCed [**10-28**].  Urine has also grown yeast, sputum grew
   pansensitive klebsiella.  Patient off pressors this AM, but BP
   labile.   Most recent sputum cx from [**10-25**] with pseudomonas and
   klebsiella, sensitive to cefepime and tobramycin.
   - Continue inhaled tobramycin based on sensitivities and ID recs and
   cefepime (day#10 of 21 day course)
   - patient was briefly on pressors last night but not this AM
   - f/u blood cultures from [**10-30**]
   .
   # Acute on chronic --  Pt was off lasix drip overnight but had very
   good response to it earlier.  Cr stable at 2.6-2.7 for last three days,
   so his kidneys appear stable. Renal failure presumed to be due to ATN,
   so he may be also having his post-ATN diuresis.
   - Restarted lasix gtt this AM per Renal recs at low dose for net I/O
   goal of -500cc
   - f/u renal recs
   .
   # Gallstone Pancreatitis
 clinically appears to be improved, tolerated
   [**Month/Year (2) **] tube feeds
   - continue erythromycin for gastric motility
   .

 pt has type II DM on insulin

   - continue to monitor Hct

   .

The patient's goals of care include daily updates for the family and out-of-bed (OOB) activities in the ICU. The patient is receiving various treatments and medications to manage his conditions and prevent complications.

2. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure is likely secondary to klebsiella pneumonia. Continuous treatment with cefepime and inhaled tobramycin is recommended based on the sensitivity results. Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a critically ill individual with multiple medical complications. They have respiratory failure, renal failure, pancreatitis, and anemia. The patient's condition is being closely monitored in the ICU. They have been experiencing negative fluid balance, hypotension requiring vasopressor support, and difficulty weaning off the ventilator due to dyspnea. The patient also complains of chest discomfort, which may be related to cardiac issues as indicated by a new left bundle branch block (LBBB) on ECG. Other issues include impaired airway clearance, impaired balance and gait, impaired motor function, impaired ventilation, and impaired skin integrity. The patient has a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), diabetes mellitus type II, hypertension, and chest pain. They are currently on various medications and treatments, including antibiotics, analgesics, and renal replacement therapy.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory system is compromised, leading to difficulty in breathing and maintaining adequate oxygenation.
2. Renal Failure: The patient's kidneys are not functioning properly, resulting in inadequate filtration and excretion of waste products.
3. Pancreatitis: Inflammation of the pancreas is present, which can lead to complications such as abdominal pain, organ dysfunction, and systemic inflammation.
4. Anemia: The patient has low levels of red blood cells, leading to reduced oxygen-carrying capacity and potential tissue hypoxia.
5. Chest Pain: The patient is experiencing discomfort in the chest, which may be indicative of cardiac involvement or other thoracic pathology.
6. Impaired Airway Clearance: The patient's ability to clear secretions and mucus from the airways is compromised, increasing the risk of pneumonia or other respiratory infections.
7. Impaired Balance and Gait: The patient exhibits impaired balance and coordination, which can lead to falls and injuries.
8. Impaired Motor Function: The patient has reduced muscle strength and control, affecting their ability to move and perform daily activities.
9. Impaired Ventilation: The patient's respiratory muscles are weakened, making it difficult to maintain adequate ventilation and gas exchange.
10. Impaired Skin Integrity: The patient's skin is at risk of breakdown and pressure ulcers due to prolonged immobility and inadequate tissue perfusion.

It is important to closely monitor and manage these potential complications to improve the patient's overall condition and prevent further deterioration.

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an 83-year-old male with a history of pancreatitis, respiratory failure, sepsis, and improving renal failure. The patient has been treated for klebsiella pneumonia and is currently on a 21-day course of cefepime. He also has underlying COPD and is being treated with MDIs including albuterol.

The patient presented with chest pain, which was initially thought to be cardiac-related but later determined not to be cardiac pain. The EKG showed a left bundle branch block (LBBB), which the patient had in the past. The cardiac enzymes were negative, so no cardiac intervention was taken.

The patient has been diagnosed with sepsis caused by coag-negative staphylococcal bacteremia and yeast growing from the catheter tip. He has been treated with vancomycin and micafungin, both of which were discontinued on October 28th. The patient's sputum also grew pansensitive klebsiella.

The patient's renal function has been improving, with a stable creatinine level of 2.5. His kidneys appear stable, and he is being closely monitored by the renal team. The patient was off the lasix drip overnight but had a good response to it earlier, so it was restarted at a low dose.

The patient has a history of gallstone pancreatitis and has tolerated PEG tube feeds well. He is being treated with eryth

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an 83-year-old male with a diagnosis of pancreatitis, respiratory failure, sepsis, and improving renal failure. The patient has several medical conditions including type II diabetes mellitus, anemia with a history of GI bleed, depression/anxiety, and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).

The patient's current vital signs include a temperature of 36.8°C, heart rate of 77 bpm, blood pressure of 110/36 mmHg, respiratory rate of 17 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 99%. The patient is on a ventilator in CPAP/PSV mode with a tidal volume of 463 mL, peak inspiratory pressure of 14 cmH2O, positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) of 5 cmH2O, and an FiO2 of 50%.

The patient's physical examination reveals distant heart sounds, regular heart rhythm without murmurs/rubs/gallops, rhonchorous sounds in the anterior upper chest, positive bowel sounds with distended abdomen but slightly softer than yesterday, and 3+ edema in both upper and lower extremities slightly increased from yesterday.

Laboratory results show a white blood cell count of 11.2 K/uL, hemoglobin of 7.6 g/dL, platelet count of 242 K/uL, blood urea nitrogen (BUN) of 30 mg/dL, creatinine of 2.4 mg/dL, sodium of 138 mEq/L, potassium of 3.8 mEq/L, glucose of 69 mg/dL, and calcium of 8.0 mg/dL. Other lab values are within normal limits.

The patient has been treated with multiple medications including cefepime, tobramycin, vancomycin, micafungin, vasopressin, furosemide (Lasix), erythromycin, glargine, and citalopram. The patient also has a tracheostomy tube in place, a PEG tube, and a multi-lumen central venous catheter.

The potential medical complications that can arise include:
1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status remains unstable with ongoing support on the ventilator. The presence of pseudomonas and klebsiella in the sputum may contribute to respiratory failure.
2. Sepsis: Despite receiving appropriate antibiotic therapy, the patient remains at risk for sepsis due to the presence of yeast in the urine and catheter tip.
3. Renal failure: The patient's renal function is improving but still requires close monitoring and management with Lasix.
4. Volume overload: The patient is experiencing volume overload as indicated by the high fluid balance and edema.
5. Pressure injuries: The patient's immobility and edema increase the risk for pressure injuries.
6. Infection: The patient is at risk for further infections due to the presence of catheters and immunocompromised state.
7. Anemia: The patient's anemia needs to be closely monitored and managed appropriately.
8. Diabetes: The patient's diabetes needs to be managed with insulin therapy.
9. Depression/anxiety: The patient's mental health needs to be addressed with continued encouragement and medication.

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:

The patient is an 83-year-old male with a history of pancreatitis, respiratory failure, sepsis, and improving renal failure. He is currently being treated for klebsiella pneumonia and has been diagnosed with coag-negative staph bacteremia and yeast growing from the catheter tip. The patient's respiratory failure is likely secondary to klebsiella pneumonia and volume overload in the setting of acute renal failure. He is on pressure support and being weaned off vasopressin.

The patient's sepsis is being treated with a full course of vancomycin and micafungin, both of which were discontinued on 10/28. His sputum has also grown yeast, and his urine has grown yeast as well. The patient's underlying COPD is being treated with MDIs including albuterol.

The patient's acute on chronic kidney condition is being managed with lasix drip to achieve a net input/output goal of -500mL for today, with no more than 1L per day. His renal function appears stable, with a creatinine level of 2.4.

The patient's gallstone pancreatitis seems to be clinically improving and he is tolerating PEG tube feeds. He is being continued on erythromycin for gastric motility.

The patient has type II diabetes and is on insulin. He is being continued on glargine 38u qhs and ISS.

The patient has a history

The patient is a 69-year-old male with a history of respiratory failure, renal failure, pancreatitis, hypotension, diabetes mellitus type II, hypertension, and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). - PICC LINE - START on 10/31/2153 at 05:00 PM

- Chronic pain

1. Chest pain
2. Severe sepsis with organ dysfunction
3. Ineffective coping

Summary:
The patient is an 83-year-old male with a history of pancreatitis, respiratory failure, sepsis, and improving renal failure. He has been diagnosed with gallstone pancreatitis, pneumonia caused by klebsiella and pseudomonas, coag-negative staph bacteremia, and yeast infection. The patient has chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), diabetes mellitus type II, anemia, and depression/anxiety. He is currently on mechanical ventilation and receiving treatment for his various conditions, including antibiotics and other medications. The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.9°C, heart rate of 72 bpm, blood pressure of 137/50 mmHg, respiratory rate of 11 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 100%. Physical examination reveals crackles in the anterior upper chest, edema in both upper and lower extremities, and a positive blood glucose level of 202 mg/dL. Laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count, decreased hemoglobin, elevated creatinine level, and abnormal liver function tests. The patient's fluid balance is positive with a total input of 1,499 mL and output of 2,425 mL since midnight. The patient is currently on a lasix drip to manage fluid overload and is being monitored closely.

Potential medical complications that can arise:
1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status may deteriorate further due to the ongoing infection and underlying COPD

4. Anemia: The patient has anemia, which may be contributing to their overall poor condition. Further evaluation and management of anemia is required.

5. Pancreatitis: The patient has acute pancreatitis, as indicated by inflammation seen on CT scan and elevated lip

The patient has type II diabetes and is on insulin. His Hct levels are stable, indicating that his anemia is under control. He is being monitored closely for any signs of GI bleeding. The patient's goals of care include continuing daily physical therapy and trying to get him out of bed daily. Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is an 83-year-old male with a history of pancreatitis, respiratory failure, sepsis, and improving renal failure. He is currently in the ICU and has been on mechanical ventilation. His vital signs include a temperature of 37.6°C, heart rate of 95 bpm, blood pressure ranging from 121/51 mmHg to 87/46 mmHg, respiratory rate of 15 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 95%. The patient is alert but has difficulty speaking. Physical examination reveals decreased breath sounds at the bases and lateral chest, clear anterior chest, and diffuse wheezing sounds. There is also evidence of edema in both lower extremities. Laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count, slightly decreased hemoglobin level, and normal platelet count. Other lab values are within normal limits. Radiology shows large bilateral pleural effusions. 

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory status is compromised due to klebsiella pneumonia and volume overload in the setting of acute renal failure. There is a concern about the size of the pleural effusions, which may further impair his breathing.
2. Fluid Overload: The patient is highly fluid overloaded, as indicated by his CXR and fluid balance (+30 L). This could lead to worsening respiratory failure and other complications.
3. Intravascular Depletion: The patient may be intravascularly depleted

   83 yo M w/ prolonged hospital course in setting of severe GS

   volume overload w/ third spacing, pulm edema and effusions on
   underlying significant COPD with chronic CO2 retention.  His abd
   remains distended further impacting his resp status and ability to wean
   from vent.
   Agree with plan to continue PSV.  He seems to need the PEEP in setting
   of b/l pleural effusions and persistent abd distention.  Does not
   appear ready for more aggressive wean to TC.  Will consider tapping his
   effusions, though with his low albumin suspect fluid will
   reaccumulate.  He remains on cef and inhaled tobra to complete a 21 day
   course for psa/kleb pna.  He is af now and wbc is trending down.
   Suspect his cr is at a new baseline.  He remains  total body vol
   overloaded but intravascularly dry with BUN increasing in setting of
   diuresis.  He remains anemic, but without evidence of acute bleeding or
   hct drop. Would hold on additional lasix and allow to re-equilibrate.
   Would consider additional fluid boluses with albumin. No other
   indication for colloid at this time.  Continue epo.
   He continue to work with PT and is getting OOB to chair.

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is an 83-year-old male with a prolonged hospital course due to severe acute pancreatitis complicated by multiple organ dysfunction syndrome (MODS). He has been experiencing respiratory failure, acute renal failure on continuous renal replacement therapy (CRI), and has a positive blood culture for PSA/Klebsiella pneumonia. The patient also has total body volume overload with third spacing, pulmonary edema, and effusions, as well as significant chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) with chronic carbon dioxide retention. His abdomen remains distended, which further impacts his respiratory status and ability to wean from the ventilator. 

The patient's laboratory results show leukocytosis (increased white blood cell count), anemia, elevated lactate levels, and elevated D-dimer levels. Imaging reveals large effusions layering beneath the patient. 

Assessment and Plan:
1. Respiratory failure: The patient remains ventilator-dependent on pressure support ventilation (PSV) due to resolving ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP), ongoing volume overload with third spacing, pulmonary edema, and effusions. There is also significant abdominal distention impacting his respiratory status and ability to wean from the ventilator.
2. Acute renal failure (ARF) on CRI: The patient's renal function is being managed with continuous renal replacement therapy (CRI).
3. PSA/Klebsiella pneumonia: The patient is being treated with cef

The patient is an 83-year-old male with severe acute pancreatitis, multiorgan dysfunction syndrome (MODS), acute respiratory failure, and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). The patient is currently on mechanical ventilation and has been in the ICU for an extended period of time. 

Key findings from the progress note include:
- The patient's vital signs are relatively stable, with a blood pressure of 142/59 mmHg and heart rate of 89 bpm.
- The patient's respiratory support consists of CPAP/PSV mode ventilation with a tidal volume (Vt) of 422 mL, positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) of 5 cmH2O, fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) of 50%, and respiratory system compliance (RSBI) of 56.
- Laboratory results show an elevated white blood cell count (WBC) of 14.4 K/uL, hemoglobin (Hct) of 28.4%, platelet count (Plt) of 295 K/uL, creatinine (Cr) level of 2.3 mg/dL, and blood urea nitrogen (BUN) level of 34 mg/dL.
- Imaging reveals large effusions layering.
- The patient's abdomen remains distended, which further impacts his respiratory status and ability to wean from the ventilator.
- The patient is still dependent on the ventilator due to resolving ventilator-associated pneumonia

   lasix, due to inability to mobilize fluid
   - lasix gtt stopped as patient is diuresing well on own after fluid
   bolus.  Since increase in UOP was fluid responsive, patient may be
   intravascularly depleted and not mobilizing third space fluid fast
   enough (LOS Fluid balance: +30 L). Minimal UOP should be at least 40-80

 1 liter today if possible
   - Since UOP is not responsive to lasix; likely volume down. Hold lasix
   for now and check I/O
s at 2 pm. If UOP is not at least 0.5 cc/hr

   colloid.

   will likely offer little benefit as it will likely re-accumulate. Hold

   Assessment and Plan
   Mr. [**Known lastname 9611**] is an 83M with pancreatitis, with respiratory failure, sepsis,
   and improving renal failure.
   .
   # Respiratory failure
   Respiratory failure likely secondary to klebsiella pneumonia and
   worsened by volume overload in the setting of acute renal failure.   On
   pressure support [**8-29**] but feels tired.  Based on CXR, patient is highly
   fluid overloaded in lungs which is likely compromising his respiratory
   status; but currently having difficulty diuresing him to make progress
   decreasing his pleural effusions
   - Patient having difficulty mobilizing fluid to be able to diurese
   well, will trial 50g albumin to build up his intravascular volume and
   then restart lasix gtt after a bolus of lasix with a goal urine output
   of 80-100cc/hr.  Will also type and screen the patient as he may
   benefit from a unit of PRBC
s if he is unable to diurese with albumin.
   - Pleural effusions likely transudate from volume overload. Tapping
   will likely offer little benefit as it will likely re-accumulate. Hold
   off for now and re-assess as needed.
   - Continue cefepime and inhaled tobra as per ID recs (day #18 of 21 day
   course)
   - treat pt
s underlying COPD with MDIs, incl albuterol
   - Attempt to wean PS down to 5 if patient can tolerate.
   - f/u blood cx from [**10-30**]
NGTD
   - will discuss possibly decreasing volume of tube feeds to help keep
   the patient net negative
   .
   # Acute on chronic renal failure
 Essentially stable Cr 2.[**5-27**] be new
   baseline, BUN increased from 103 to 114; further supporting possible
   intravascular volume depletion.
   - UOP goal of 80-100cc/hr, with reinitiation of lasix gtt with albumin
   to try and mobilize his extravascular volume
   - pm lytes
   - Regarding increasing BUN, as been guaiac positive and has hx of GI
   bleed in past, so possibly related to GI bleed, but Hct stable for now,
   will continue IV PPI
   - cont to monitor Hct and BUN and guaiac stools
   .
   # DM
 pt has type II DM on insulin
   - continue glargine 38u qhs
   - continue ISS
   .
   # Anemia
   Hx of GI bleed.  Hct stable
   - get active type and screen
   - continue to monitor Hct, especially with coffee grounds from NGT last
   week
   - continue EPO
   - continue IV PPI
   .
   # Depression/anxiety:
   - Continue citalopram 40mg and encouragement
   - place on Passe-Miur Valve on w cuff deflated (Still attached to Vent)
   when family comes once/day to allow him to communicate; if respiratory
   status allows
   .
   # Goals of care:
   - continue daily Physical therapy and try to get pt out of bed daily

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an 83-year-old male with a history of pancreatitis, respiratory failure, sepsis, and improving renal failure. The patient's current medical conditions include respiratory failure, acute on chronic renal failure, diabetes mellitus, anemia, and depression/anxiety. 

Potential medical complications that can arise include worsening respiratory failure due to fluid overload, difficulty diuresing and mobilizing fluid, re-accumulation of pleural effusions, further deterioration of renal function, uncontrolled diabetes mellitus, exacerbation of anemia, and potential worsening of depression/anxiety.

The patient's treatment plan includes continuing cefepime and inhaled tobramycin as per ID recommendations, attempting to wean pressure support down to 5 if the patient can tolerate, initiating a trial of 50g albumin to build up intravascular volume followed by restarting lasix gtt with a goal urine output of 80-100cc/hr, typing and screening the patient for potential blood transfusion if needed, and discussing possibly decreasing the volume of tube feeds to help keep the patient net negative.

Please note that this summary is based solely on the information provided in the progress note.

   volume overload w/ third spacing, pulm edema and effusions on
   underlying significant COPD with chronic CO2 retention.  His abd
   remains distended further impacting his resp status and ability to wean
   from vent.  Primary issue at this time remains ability to mobilize

   rise which we suspect is related to itnravscaulr depletion despite
   total body vol overload.  Issue of slow gi bleed remains in ddx given
   bun rise without subsequent  cr bump.  He is heme neg with slow drop in
   hct.  We continue epo, keep t and cross active and note no obvious
   active evidence of gi bleed.    He remains total body vol overloaded
   but intravascularly dry with BUN increasing most likely [**2-26**] diuresis
   and intravascular depletion.  He remains anemic, but without evidence
   of acute bleeding or hct drop. Would hold on additional lasix today and
   allow to re-equilibrate.  Would consider additional fluid bolus with
   albumin. Continue epo.
   From resp status we continue PSV.  He seems to need the small amt of
   PEEP in setting of b/l pleural effusions and persistent abd
   distention.  At this time he does not appear ready for more aggressive
   wean to TC.  Will consider tapping his effusions, though suspect this
   intervention may not have much impact and with his low albumin fluid
   will reaccumulate.  He remains on cefepime and inhaled tobra to
   complete a 18/21 day course for psa/kleb pna.  He remains af now and
   his wbc continue to trend down.
   He continue to work with PT and is getting OOB to chair.

Summary:
The patient is an 83-year-old male with severe acute pancreatitis who has developed multiple complications. The potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient is still ventilator-dependent due to underlying chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), resolving ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP), and abdominal distension impacting respiratory status.

2. Acute renal failure (ARF)/acute tubular necrosis (ATN) on continuous renal replacement therapy (CRI): The patient's kidneys are not functioning properly, as indicated by rising blood urea nitrogen (BUN) levels and other lab abnormalities.

3. Pneumonia: The patient has an ongoing infection with PSA/Klebsiella pneumonia, for which he is receiving antibiotics.

4. Total body volume overload/third spacing: The patient has fluid overload with third spacing, leading to edema and effusions. This may contribute to his respiratory difficulties and inability to wean from the ventilator.

5. Depression/anxiety: The patient's mood remains very depressed, and his anxiety levels are also high. He is currently being treated with increased doses of celexa.

6. Anemia: The patient is anemic, but there is no evidence of acute bleeding or a significant drop in hemoglobin (Hct) levels.

7. Leukocytosis: Although the patient's white blood cell (WBC) count is elevated, it is improving.

8. Underlying COPD:

Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is an 83-year-old male with a prolonged hospital course due to severe acute pancreatitis. The patient's current issues include respiratory failure, acute kidney injury, resolving pneumonia, total body volume overload, depression/anxiety, anemia, and underlying chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). The patient remains ventilator-dependent and has ongoing volume overload with third spacing, pulmonary edema, and effusions on underlying significant COPD. The primary issue at this time is mobilizing fluids to the intravascular space to improve total body overload. The plan is to trial albumin with Lasix bolus followed by gtt. If there is minimal response, a packed red blood cell transfusion along with Lasix gtt will be given. The patient's creatinine is likely at a new baseline, while BUN continues to rise, which is suspected to be related to intravascular depletion and diuresis despite total body volume overload. The issue of slow gastrointestinal bleed remains in the differential diagnosis due to the rise in BUN without subsequent creatinine bump, noting prior gastrointestinal bleed in the patient, though this seems much less likely. The patient remains anemic with gradual hematocrit drop, but there is no evidence of acute active gastrointestinal bleed.

Summary:
The patient is an 83-year-old male with a history of pancreatitis, respiratory failure, sepsis, and improving renal failure. The patient has been diagnosed with respiratory failure likely secondary to klebsiella pneumonia and volume overload in the setting of renal failure. There is increased fluid in the lungs, and the patient has been switched to assisted controlled ventilation (AC) yesterday evening. The patient has a positive fluid balance of 1.2 liters for the day but negative fluid balance of 800 mL for the first 7 hours this morning, remaining 30 liters positive for the length of stay.

The patient's pleural effusions are likely transudate from volume overload. Tapping will likely offer little benefit as it will likely re-accumulate. It is advised to hold off for now and reassess as needed. The patient continues to receive cefepime and inhaled tobra as per infectious disease recommendations (day #19 of a 21-day course). The patient's underlying COPD should be treated with MDIs including albuterol. 

The patient's elevated BUN may have some effect on his mood. It is recommended to ask the renal team about continuous veno-venous hemodialysis (CVVH) or hemodialysis (HD) to address uremia and get some volume off. The patient has acute-on-chronic renal failure with a stable creatinine level of 2.3 but an increased BUN of 119. The patient's urine output has averaged 80-100 cc/hr after restarting lasix gtt last night with albumin to try and mobilize his extravascular volume. 

Regarding the increasing BUN, the patient has been guaiac positive and has a history of GI bleed in the past, so possibly related to GI bleed. However, the patient's Hct is stable for now, and it is recommended to continue IV PPI. If the patient's urine output drops off, it is advised to give 1 unit of packed red blood cells (pRBCs) for anemia and to give colloids intravascularly. 

The patient has type II diabetes mellitus (DM) and is on insulin. It is recommended to continue glargine 38u qhs and continue ISS. The patient's anemia is likely due to a history of GI bleed. It is advised to keep an active type and screen, guaiac stools, and transfuse 1 unit of pRBCs if urine output drops off. The patient should continue to monitor Hct, continue EPO, continue IV PPI, and consider changing his room to give him a new environment.

The patient's goals of care include continuing daily physical therapy and trying to get the patient out of bed daily. The patient has a PICC line, and prophylaxis for DVT, stress ulcer, and ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) bundle should be continued. The patient's code status is full code, and his disposition is unknown.
